reviewText:
This was an amazing game, and this update provides a nice fresh coat of paint and mechanics re-work, but it's all overshadowed by one of the most awful user community and social game intergrations ive ever encountered. Get ready to make another account you dont want and have your lobby filled with a bunch of players staying in your way and slowing down your computer. It's basically a terrible version of team running on top of the game, running on top of steam.

Trendy entertainment has really hurt the entire experience of their classic game in an effort to try and make it more social.

It's hard to say if it's worth it. If you can get this update for less than $10 than give it a try, but I can't recommend this over the classic experience. I recommend playing the regular version, this update is a step in the wrong direction.

reviewText:
Ok i'm on the fence on this one.... In some ways DD Eternity is BETTER then the original game, it's not another Unreal Engine start up, it's on it's own dedicated engine.. Despite what people say while it's multiplatform it looks BETTER then the original Dungeon Defenders..

HOWEVER....  The actual discription and other items for this game are deceptive. I will list everything that is DECEPTIVE about the game below.

1. There is NOTHING here to tell you that you MUST be ONLINE to play this, the original Dungeon Defenders let you play OFFLINE and LOCAL network.
2. There is NOTHING here to tell you that your going to be STREAMING 99.99% of the ASSETS on the FLY, that's right you get a 40mb dl then you have to STREAM the rest of the game, this is MAJORLY wrong.
3. This is meant to be a fully paid for game.. yet it has a 'Cosmetic' Cash Store in it.. Which it SHOULD NOT have at all.. if you pay for a game you pay for the game, not part of the game.
4. Trendy Have been deceptive in how they handled the release, how they put up information, etc.. These guys have seriously LOST a lot of the respect the community had for them.. OVERNIGHT.

reviewText:
While the improvements for this game are many. The fact that you have to purchase this version makes it far less amazing than it actually is. Because what it actually is, is an update...not an actual completely new game. This is the same game as Dungeon Defenders, just with all the fixes and some new stuff they're testing out.

I purchased Dungeon Defenders when the summer sale was happening. Which means I got everything for this game for like $20 or less (I can't really remember the price), which is a lot of DLCs and other content. This game is cheap still, at $6 for people who own DD, or $14 for people who don't. Still a good deal. But the fact that people who already own DD have to pay for this is just a money grab.

It would have been more fair for people who already own the original DD to receive this version for free while everyone else had to pay $6.

Still, if you want a solid game to play that's a mix of tower defense and action RPG, then this game is still really good, but if you already own DD, then don't waste your time unless you have money to throw away, because you're not actually getting anything of value out of this version.

reviewText:
This game...I’m shocked as to how badly they screwed up a re-release of a classic tower defense game. If you're familiar with the original dungeon defender, then a lot of things will seem very familiar, if a little unintuitive at first.

However if you’re new to this series, then I feel really bad – you are thrown into a public tavern without going through any tutorial (which the original had) and you automatically start out with the MONK, a class that according its description in the original game is designed for advanced players…but you wouldn’t know that because the developers had the genius idea of not including ANY tooltips in this re-release. Tooltips and simple descriptions of the classes were in the original version – they can’t be that hard to implement (unless there are limitations to this mobile port).

This game needs a lot of work before I can recommend it, especially for newer players.

reviewText:
To put it simply, this is a disgusting mess.

To be fair, all the new stuff is great. The new gear system, the modified progression, the consolidation and simplifying of all the DLC... all of that is really nice. The problem is the unholy layer of oily grime and garbage it's all buried underneath.

The UI is beyond clunky. It actually feels like it's even working against the player at times. Doing even the simplest of tasks requires navigating menu upon menu, where the original game has everything right there waiting for you. And it's all just so slow.

The new tavern system is atrocious. Gone forever are the charming personal taverns, decorated with trophies and awards. But the really important part is how you are now forced into a crowded, public tavern. It lags, it's loud, and all the while the chat is popping up over your menus you're trying to navigate. Be prepared to inspect multiple players instead of opening the forge or shop because the tavern is so overcrowded. What used to be a place of relaxation between missions is now just as chaotic as the missions themselves.

Even the tavern itself is a mess: The Tavernkeep is still behind the counter for all your shopping needs... but the new crafting guy is on the balcony above him. This places every single useful aspect of the tavern as far away from each other as possible, leaving you to run around all over the place when all you want to do is get set up for the next mission. Also, for some reason some of the practice dummies have been removed. Want to test your new weapon? Well get in line, because so do the other dozen people in your tavern!

Customization seems to be a mixed bag. Your character wears their gear now, which is neat, and you can even dye it with a wide selection of colors. (This is extra fun with the Jester/Fool, who like to just kinda slap the gear onto their bodies wherever they'd like.) However, you can no longer customize your crystal or your character's base colors on creation. They gave some, but they also took some.

One of the big draws is the usable items, like the amulets. They're kinda neat, but really, I feel like they're unnecessary and just serve to dilute the diversity of the character classes a bit. Also, the pet eggs are weird. The game gives you a pet, but you must carry it in an item slot and watch it do nothing for a while until the game decides you may start using it. This is somehow considered fun and a positive addition to the game.

Speaking of fun
date: there's also a crafting system. Maybe this is a personal opinion, but I've never seen the appeal to these things. They jsut seem to be this weird fad game mechanic that everyone puts into their games nowadays. I've never heard of anyone saying Wow
recommended: a crafting system! I am so excited for that!" Honestly I don't see the draw of the game giving me a weapon
hoursPlayed: but telling me I can't use it until I collect an arbitrary number of useless doodads.\n\nFinally
voteText: there's the biggest elephant in the room... the always online system. This is another one of those cases where
helpfulPercent: if you want to play your game
votesHelpful: you're at the mercy of the servers. No offline play at all here
votesTotal: not even for single player. (There isn't even a single player mode. You just have to make a private room and not invite anyone in. But you still have to deal with the public tavern.) And someday
votesFunny: when the servers die forever

reviewText:
Always online. No split screen. Stay away.
Don't get me wrong, if this was simply a bundle of the Dungeon Defenders series, it would be well more than worth it...but ALWAYS ONLINE. And many other bad changes.
Okay, maybe you live in the mystical wonderland of internet where you get more than 1 provider, and one of them is actually reliable, so what's this new version all about?

Slightly revised UI. I actually really dislike the fact that when you hit the inventory button, only a tiny bit of the screen is used to show the stats of the character, and you have to go through more than 1 window to look at your gear. The item box thing is a good bit more clunky, as you now have to choose your hero from there instead of when you're loading in, so, quite unneccesary.
Supposedly more secure online play. I can't attest for or against this.
4 more maps. Yeah, I got through one of the new maps before I got fed up with the horrible load times. Pretty on par with current maps.
Did I mention there's no split screen? You can't play with friends unless they buy their own computer and this game. Kinda annoying, especially when the previous version had it in.

BUGS. By god. So many bugs. Can't even log in half the time because of them. (and that's not an exaggeration, literally every other time I tried I got kicked out because of something like AsAdmin doesn't like you" or some nonsense like that

reviewText:
Probably one of the best Tower Defense games on the market if not the best.

Dungeon defenders Eternity is essentially a definitive version of the original dungeon defenders with most of the DLC included and new additions to boot. The game boasts redone combat mechanics, changing some of the different weapons to make them stronger or more balanced while still keeping every character useful at core.

The main objective of this game is to defend the eternia crystals from the onslaught of hundreds to thousands of orcs. mages, goblins, ect. Each level feels fair for every class and keeps the original feel of the game even with the minor changes. The levels at an aesthetic level are beautiful and rich and the music is to die for.

Honestly I cannot recommend this game more to anyone who is a fan of the original Dungeon Defenders.

reviewText:
Review as of Content Update 1:

I feel this game has gotten a bad rap.  Yes, it is the original game rehashed, but that was made clear prior to release.  Yes, it has new features, but more or less it plays like the original.  As an owner of the base games of both, this is the one that I prefer.

Graphics 7/10 - They choose a slightly different style for DDE and I personally liked the style of the original better.  The graphics don't seem as clear and crisp as the original.  They even have a warning about streaming textures....why can't I opt to download these?

Sound 10/10 - This game has some ridiculously addictive music.  I've caught myself humming along with bits of it.  A family member who played it breifly said the same thing.  Some sound effects could use a little more oomph but that's about the only downside I could say.

Gameplay 8/10 - I'd love to give this game a 10/10 here if not for one fact.  Load times.  Load times drag down the overall experience even when playing in a private lobby.  On the plus side, this game is FAR more accessable that it's predecesssor for finding gear for your characters.  Having the option of which stats that the game is comparing is a big deal for newbies especially.  The massive amounts of mana available on each map means your resources are not the limiting factor, it's more focused on your strategy.

Developer Support 10/10 - Let's face it folks, this is the game they are supporting more at this date and time.  DDE has gotten a lot of bad reviews and most of the constructive criticisms have been addressed.  It has gone from what felt like a beta release to a full release over the last few months.  Their continued support and patches will make this into an even better title.

reviewText:
Considering the popularity and quality of the first edition of Dungeon Defenders, I was surprised by the overwhelming number of negative reviews for what I'll call the *upgraded* Eternity edition. I should start by saying that my experience with the original was only about 2 hours playing the demo on Xbox 360. I was impressed but never got around to purchasing it. So I'm basically brand new to the franchise.

My friends and I have been playing some Sacntum 2 recently (and loving it), so we decided to give DD Eternity a shot. We almost didn't purchase Eternity due to the large number of negative reviews, but after canvasing the complaints most of them could be categorized as follows:

1) The UI is totally unintuitive (some say broken)
2) There aren't enough new features added over the original to really consider this a new version
3) It's online all the time
4) No single player or private modes

Let me address each of these:

1) The UI is totally unintuitive - Yah this isn't the greatest UI in the world, but it does actually work. It just takes some getting used to. But it definitely isn't broken, just suffers a bit from poor design. I wouldn't make your buying decision on this characteristic alone.

2) Not enough new features - I'm a totally new player to the franchise, so I can't speak to the evolution from the original to Eternity. But I can give my opinion on how I think the new version plays: It's fun as hell! There are quite a few classes to choose from each with their own flavor of play, tons and tons and tons of items, a variety of ways to build your characters, and the combat is smooth and easy to get used to after a few matches.

3) It's online all the time - This is true. It really boils down to personal preference. You don't have to interact with any other players, you'll just see them in the Tavern (Dungeon Defenders equivalent of a Lobby). I'm not in the habit of playing with strangers, but the online only component doesn't really bother me. They have their own online platform they are developing called Playverse which is a bit convoluted when you are trying to get a group with your friends, but it still works. We've gotten used to other platforms where you essentially invite a friend with a single click, or accept an invitation with a single click. Playverse makes you have to do like three clicks the first time to accept a friend invite, after which the invites work much easier.

4) No single player or private modes - So this game came out about a month or so ago as of this writing. I have  a feeling that the game may have launched without single player/private modes, but has since been patched to allow it. Here's the bottom line: you can absolutely play single player or private mode with up to 4 of your friends. If it's just two of you in a private match it's totally fine - you won't get any strangers added to your game. I've played several matches solo and won handily, so the difficulty must scale with more players.

Overall I would definitely recommend this game. It has a few rough edges, but these are things that can easily be improved with some patches going forward. The game is not broken as others are claiming. It plays beautifully and is a lot of fun to play either by yourself or with friends. After playing for a few hours now I felt obligated to come and write a positive review to offset the huge number of negative reviews.

reviewText:
I'll give it a thumbs up. I owned Dungeon Defenders on Xbox, but never got the dlc seeing as the PC version looked a lot better. However, I didn't really ever have money I felt was worth putting towards getting it with all the DLC. This provides a really nice way to get all that at a cheaper price. The only major downsides are that it's online only (for this type of game, I'd really prefer the choice to go online or not), and that it's horribly lacking in explanation for new players. I already had an idea of what things were coming in, so it didn't affect me too much, but it was still annoying trying to refresh my memory on what the stat pictures were. Also, I actully liked the old system where mana was money. It was cool balancing greed and need.

NOTES TO DEVELOPERS SHOULD THEY SEE:
-Please for the love of god fix the issue where your cursor goes away on a menu page when someone walks behind it. When I'm comparing stats, I don't need the popup to disappear every 4 seconds.
-GIVE ME MORE MANA FROM CHESTS IN SOLO. I understand you wanted to balance it around teams, since everyone gets their own chests. But 100 mana isn't enough for crap by yourself, making it neccessary to have a hero that can fight the waves, even if you want to build a pure tower character and watch the fight instead.

EDIT:
-They fixed the issue with the menus going away. This is fantastic. Thank you!
-They give more mana when there are fewer players on the map now. Again, thank you!

reviewText:
After seeing a lot of the more negative reviews on here I was a bit wary about getting the game at all, but after giving it some time and patience I have to say it is nothing like as terrible as some have accused it of being. In fact it has brought me back to playing the previous version and enjoying both of them again.

It does seem strange that in times when things change so fast people are so obstinate about anything being even slightly different; the reaction every time facebook makes a minimal change there is always some kind of uproar from the masses about how terrible it all it, the apocalypse is coming etc. The same seems to have happened here. There are certainly differences, and once you have got used to them the system actually works very well. Trendy have listened to all of the complaints and have made efforts to address them. There is now a single player mode that is easy to access, there are shortcuts in the item boxes for quick selling etc all of which are complaints that have been voiced over the last weeks (see below reviews)

Loading time at the beginning if you have a slower connection is a bit of a pest, but once in everything is smooth, give it some time and have some patience it is worth it in the end.

reviewText: I read all of the bad reviews of Dungeon Defenders Eternity, then waited a few days and bought it anyway. We have two accounts at my house and have been playing two person games. Overall we are enjoying it very much but there is a lot of confusion. Some things that should be simple take an internet search to figure out. Because the game is new, there is not a lot of information on the internet. Simple things like inviting friends, creating a party, and hatching eggs are just different enough to cause problems. My biggest issue is initial load time. One computer may be ready to play almost immediately while the other wants to reload a lot of graphic files. So far it seems almost random one whether a computer want to reload graphic files. We have learned to start the game, then go gather our drinks and snacks while the graphics load, then come back to play the game. With a weekend of play we only had one instance where a party member was dropped as the dungeon was loading. No time warps as far as we can tell.\n\nOver all we had a lot of fun with the updated version of a favorite game. Everyone gets their own chests so building is faster and much more even. Experience is divided evenly among characters. No more worrying about the knight and mage towers giving most of the experience to those characters. I do wish that the inventory system was easier to use. There is still a lot of junk items to go through and sell. I need to experiment with the item filters in the Options menu and see if I can filter out the items without losing the income I get from selling them.

reviewText: This is identical to the base game with a few tweaks, and as far as I'm concerned it does the franchise perfect justice. All the things people are griping about have either been implemented, announced, or are just things people came up with for the sake of whining. No, currently there aren't achievements. Yes, it's because the playverse overlay is a WiP. Yes, they COULD have just stuck with steam, but no, thats not the end-all best option. The playverse overlay will be fine when it gets finished, and the negligible balance issues will be fixed in patches LIKE THEY ALWAYS ARE FOR EVERY GAME EVER. And no, there is no cash store in the game to pay2win. If you like, you can pay cash to get emotes for your characters. Purely aesthetic, not even remotely game-changing. If you like the original, then there's little to be upset with in Eternity. And all these guys crying about the 6 dollars they spent for basically an upgraded compilation of the original and all the dlc is just mind-boggling.

reviewText:
While much of this game is the same as the first, there are a significant number of differences for me that make it worth getting, not the least of which is the level of Dev attention it is getting, which has fixed a number of starting problems, including many with the Summoner class (which stuck out for me as it is my class of choice).

The inclusion of most of the DLC content (the holiday packs and such don't seem to have made it) is something that stands out for me, especially given the price. This also means most new players will likely go for the DDE over DD1 (dungeon defenders eternity/one). New levels have been made and more to come, including one in the campaign (so far, I have not made it too far as I have been enjoying the social aspect, and testing out the classes), pets now come from eggs that hatch simply by having them on your person and you never know what you will get.

Also, gear now appears on your person in a physical way which is fun, especially when you get the full set of something. Mana is no longer the currency, coins are, which drop from creatures just like mana, and are used to upgrade your items. However you can no longer buy weapons or pets from the barkeep (as of yet). There IS an ingame cash shop, but the only thing in it is emotes for your characters at a dollar each. Dyes are also available now with the barkeep, as well as a new crafting system.

For crafting, recipes drop from mobs, and materials seem to only drop from chests (though I could easily be wrong, i tend to get caught up in the action). You can choose to join your own private tavern, or a public one with other people milling about. There are even more new features that I could mention but I am sure you could find more complete lists out there.

IN CONCLUSION:

I find this game to be quite a bit more fun than the original right now given it is easier to join people of my own level, there is more details on the games I am joining, I can host private if I really want to and only invite my own friends, and it has stopped me being booted out for not having that one awesome piece of gear or whatever other reason people saw fit.

The only downside I saw, no offline play, which I do hope comes later, but I understand why not if it doesn't.

reviewText:
Lots of negative reviews, so here is a positive one.  I have 100s of hours into the original DD and all of the DLC.  DD is one of my favorite Co-Op games.

PROS:  DD Eternity is a nice refresh of the original.  I felt it had enough new stuff to offer to feel like a fairly fresh experience.  It's still the same game for the most part, but has a bit of a facelift.  There are a few new boards, tons of new gear, more gear sets, and special items that boost loot quality, stats and other things.  There is also a lot of new character cusomization.  I really like that all of the characters no longer look identical.  The biggest pro is they are continuing to update and add to the game, giving you more to look forward to.  Also, the issue with taverns not being private is fixed.

CONS:  IT's the same game. If you are looking for an ALL new experience, you won't get that here.  The game is very Internet-reliant.  if you have a poor connection, you will have issues.  The updates take a long time to download and apply.  The balance is a smidge off (The first few waves are easy, then oh-my-gosh!)   I'm not crazy about the Playverse interface, I much prefer Steam (though they are adding some Steam integration)  Most of the issues I have are minor quibbles.

If you enjoyed DD and haven't played in awhile, you will enjoy this game.

reviewText: Dungeon Defenders Eternity is basically a repackaging of the original Dungeon Defenders. They cleaned it up, balanced it, added visually appealing armor, heaps more armor sets(besides the leather, chain, plate and pristine that they used to have), and cleaned up the multiplayer to further prevent hacking or save editing. This game is worth the money, because it packages the best dlc and challenge maps together in one game so you don't have to download every dlc or shift through forums to find which are the best ones, all while offering itself to you for a lowered price. A lot of people complain about the game, but that is just them looking for some attention; People who complain about getting a more cleaned up version of a great game for 4 dollars.\n\n

reviewText:
TL;DR: Buy it if you haven't played Dungeon Defenders and you like ARPGs and Tower Defense.

Although many people were disappointed with this game upon release, me included, this game is worth looking at. A lot of the disappointment had to do with promises that weren't quite delivered upon.

Yet, upon revisiting this game, I find all the things that made the original Dungeon Defenders one of my favourite games of all time. Yet at a fraction of the cost. Sure it has problems, but this game is so diverse and puts in so many elements, of course it is going to be a mess. It is like Bethesda games: Open to play around with, tons of stuff to do, but similarly quite a few problems. If you want a game experience that is polished to the utmost and blanced, move on. If you don't mind a few uncomfortable edges and corners on a game that delivers tons of fun, jump right in.

reviewText:
Whilst the trailer shows some good new improvements, new UI, new animations, armour appearing on heroes etc. there is a lot missing when compared to the previous version of the game.

Most notably there is no way to play single-player, private matches or local splitscreen. Also, whilst the new UI looks nicer in places, in others it looks unfinished, and in general seems to be less intuitive (e.g. info text whilst building only appears after 0.5 of hovering, not instantly)

I like the idea of trying out new improvements on the old version of the game, to see which features are well received so they can be added to DD2, but with the amount lost in the transition, this is worth no more than a free beta to owners of the original DD. Really, this is an unfinished package, that should only be released as early access in its current state, but with DD2 in public testing, this wouldn't make any sense either.

reviewText:
Totally terrible. Avoid.
I loved Dungeon Defenders 1, even if they never fixed the horrible buggy PS3 version (it was basically impossible to get all the trophies because the game would crash), the PC version was really fun and addictive.

This? This is crap, it should be flagged as Early Access considering how buggy, crippled and awkward it is. Downright terrible. I has already crashed in a wide variety of ways for me. - Micro payments. Seriously, micro payments.
- Terrible GUI navigation and design - and the third party overlay is just another eyesore.

In short, I was shocked at the poor quality and execution of this product. If I could, I'd ask Steam for my money back.

reviewText: dde is marketed as the Definitive" DD experience. After having played thousands of hrs. of DD I had high hopes for dde. Sadly it is just too radical a departure from what captivated me in the original game. It is an action RPG tower defense game like the original that has the same char. with diff. abilities and balancing. Many of the mechanics and much of the gameplay style is changed for the sake of making the game play like what I'm assuming dd2 will be like instead of staying with the tried and true of what DD did right and fixing issues and refining what worked there. It is saved server side so it requires a constant internet connection as well and suffers from lag routinely due to this fact. Some like it due to the fact there is less a problem with hackers but for me it is not enough to make or keep me playing it I will stick to the original."
voteText: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Okay, before I go into details (this will mainly compare it with the original): is the game still fun with friends? Yes.
This remake/redo/whatever did improve and balance the gameplay, which was definitely needed. That is one major positive.

However, it threw away so many of the basic elements that made the original a great game. I am unable to stay in the same lobby with my friends between matches, instead it boots them to some random server. The original had it great, keeping us all in the same place, instead of making me reinvite and reconnect every time we start or fail a map/tavern.
By the same token, because the servers are now externally hosted (I understand - helps control hacking), my ping is so much higher. This isn't such a bad issue when there are not too many monsters, but later on, it is a real pain.
The microtransactions, well I don't really care too much about them: they're mainly just for taunts, which are not needed.
However the shop is so much less intuitive and instead of making everything easier, it became much the opposite. It tried to improve on sorting, which is good, but it still fails to have a filter for a certain type of armor. Considering you get set bonuses, it would be better to have this.
Also you don't get the bonuses from two weapons, instead everytime you swap your weapons, your towers get the current weapon's stats. This is fine for balance, except everytime I press z" to swap weapons
date: my towers are half damaged. It would be easier just to have the one weapon so I can easily replace it when I get better ones
recommended: or have an option to have 1 or 2.\n\nYeah
hoursPlayed: just my rant.\n\nTL;DR : Gameplay - Good
voteText: Everything else - Kinda disappointing."
helpfulPercent: September 16, 2014

votesFunny: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Microtransactions have no place in paid games.  The fact that they're there leads me to believe that this game is set to go F2P in the future - after they've made as much as they can off sales.  I refuse to play this game until the cash shop has been removed.

I was one of the silly people to buy this game when it was first released, belieiving that it was a finished product instead of the Early Access title that it really is.  When I was told of the microtransaction shop right after i bought it and all the severe game-breaking bugs in it, i was furious.

Little or no response was given by the devs other than this being a test bench for Dungeon Defenders 2 (which I've been told it will be a F2P game) - yet all the information I've found on the next Nom Nom/Trendy game to come out has led me to a non-Dungeon Defenders game that looks like it's graphically and engine-wise identical.  It's a game called Monster Madness.

I honestly feel I've been scammed.

If you too feel this game should have been labeled and had and EARLY ACCESS warning to it, you should write Steam Support and ask for a refund.  If enough people do this, the game will get yanked until they get things fixed or an Early Access put on it and a warning that it has Microtransactions ingame.

Look familiar?
https://search.yahoo.com/search;_ylt=AuLfd33JnfzCsxph8UEsyimbvZx4

reviewText:
Okay, so I've gotten down about 50 hours or so of casual play on the old DD. It was frustrating at times, but rewarding I feel when everything went as planned. Now we come to this. I read on the store page that it's somehow better and balanced and stuff. I'm like...sure, the game had a few things here and there that could have been taken care of. So might as well take it and give it a go.

Weeeeeellllllp, even with the discount that was I managed to get it, it's still a very dissapointing experience.

The graphics are better I admit, they look pretty awesome too. The item mods that appear on you are a nice addition too and you can color them with dyes as well, which is even more awesome.

Aaand that would conclude my pro's for it. The neutral stuff, is well it's just the same deal, which isn't really bad in my opninion but take it as you may in the end, as everyone has their own feelings about that.

And the cons? well, there are quite a few in my case.
1. Look I understand a downloader and installer on the same launcher that does both things at the same time. Though, pray tell me why dit it feel like warming up my proccessor during that, I have no problems with heating when steam downloads other games.

2. FFS can you all just take some time to add some more ♥♥♥♥ing video options? The classic DD had ♥♥♥♥ for options ingame, and just a few basic things in it's launcher. I personally dont own a high end machine, and being able to remove certain details" would improve my performance. And dont get me started on the "OOOH BUT IT TAKES AWAY FROM THE EXPERIENCE"....Look the last thing I care about when building ♥♥♥♥ and fighting crap is how nice and surreal the shading looks okay? and in my case it's just taxing my CPU and such.

3. WHAT THE ACTUAL ♥♥♥♥? The first time you enter you are placed in a tavern full of random players
date: faaar away from the feel of the nice and cozy private one you had in the last game. Figuring out how to do stuff is just a chore and there's no tutorials that I could find ingame to explain ♥♥♥♥ to me as some things are different than the last game. Also can you ♥♥♥♥ing clean up the ingame store? I nearly bought stuff for real cash
hoursPlayed: and like someone else said
voteText: somehow it's even more of a mess than the old inventory/box/shop thing.\n\n4. Is this a game coded for mobile platforms and ported to PC? It barely feels optimized

reviewText:
I barely write reviews but I want to give in my 2 cent opinions since I have played both DD1 and DDE. Most are already listed in the other reviews.
Pros : Starting over is pretty fun.
New maps
All characters unlocked.
Skins provided.
Tavern with other players! Can shout for party invites.
Items now show! Stylists would love this feature.
More item slots!
Coins and consumables! Amulets to help you.
Mystery eggs! Hatch them!

Cons:
Nightmare/Mixmode is not up.
Hardcore I heard is permadeath, may be fun for daredevils but I'm already having trouble finding gears.
Can't open your own shop or decorate your own tavern.
Can only see games opened by people in your tavern.
Can't see people selling items.
Can't switch characters in survival to level yourself.
Playverse gets confusing and seems pointless besides the party system. Should've just used steam to add buddies.
Aquanos has a glitchy area where the wyverns or flying eels circle around and not enter map.
Summoners now are just DPS pet" users
date: something that I feel a hunter should be having. A strong pet.\nSummoner's archers stay slow and weak
recommended: can't even pass easy mode deeper well solo when starting.\nNot sure how some people are doing 5mil dps already with 3 full level 60's geared up on first week
hoursPlayed: later to find out it's from Palantir insane boss fight while being lied to about survival.\nONE HUGE pet peeve is that
voteText: when you d/c from a private game. You can not rejoin it even if you are in the party with all 3.\n\nOver all it's fun but I'm hesitating to play because I can't find a nice game to join. Sometimes my tavern doesn't even have any Insane games. Should combine all the game rooms."

reviewText:
If I had to describe DDE in one word, it would be Disappointment.

If my money has gone to make the game better in later updates, awesome, but what it feels like is everything that was good about the first game has been sucked out and replaced by things that might cash in on casual gamers like in-app purchases and novelty items.

The interface... seriously poor form. Trendy.. you need to fire your UX and UI designers immediately. Even for a touchscreen interface it sucks, and it should have been ripped out for the PC version entirely. The icons are awful, the layout is clumsy and the overcrowding is just typical of terrible, terrible modern tablet based shovelware.

There are definitely positives but gutting the local games in favour of heavily laden DRM based, nickle and diming microtransactions really, really turns me off continuing to play it and hoping it might get better.

The worst part is no local co-op, the only reason my wife got into Dungeon Defenders in the first place...

... oh but you could buy two copies of the game and play on two screens!?!

Yeah, and I could also put a rusty nail through my scrotum too!

reviewText:
BEWARE! This is an incomplete port (Yes port) of a port of Dungeon Defenders for Tablets. While it says it has all the DLC included, it actually limits you access to parts of it. (Including nightmare difficulty and character levels above 60)

While It does have new features, it's also bogged down by failed rebalancing, server connection issues, a cow carcass worth of little bugs that make the game a mostly playable hassle.

Either get the original Dungeon Defenders, or wait for the sequel. Only get Eternity if you REALLY need to play with a friend with a tablet.

reviewText:
More DD whats not to like, Game is still as slow to get going as orginal but thats the nature of the game genre. They have improved some things and made somethings worse. Pets and useable items and extra actives are the big 3 that have seen major improvement.

Problems at the minute are the servers and in peak time ive seen some lag but nothing ground breaking game is still easily playable.

For the cost of £4 if you already own DD its worth picking up just for the extra maps and missions.

reviewText: I'm having more fun with it than the original... Original 35 hours. This one I've clocked almost 24 hours on already and have had it for a few days only. It was also nice getting all the DLC for 5 bucks, as I didn't have it previously. The only thing that is really a concern right now is latency, which has been $#!+ for me the past day. Before I was playing fine but I can't play at all today, which is something that will probably be fixed (tons of people are lagging from what I've been reading). I don't understand all the hate coming from the community myself. It almost seems like they hate it just for existing, because... Reasons which got patched in a day to a week from release? They changed and rebalanced the game. Appearently the original had hacked items everywhere as well due to everything being kept locally. I really don't see any reason to hate the game so much.\n\nBottom line, there are Pros and Cons to the game. It came out a week ago running on new software they made, and they aren't a huge studio. I expect them to continue improving and putting more content into it. If you look at everything they have been doing you should come to this conclusion too.

reviewText:
I barely write reviews but I want to give in my 2 cent opinions since I have played both DD1 and DDE. Most are already listed in the other reviews.
Pros : Starting over is pretty fun.
New maps
All characters unlocked.
Skins provided.
Tavern with other players! Can shout for party invites.
Items now show! Stylists would love this feature.
More item slots!
Coins and consumables! Amulets to help you.
Mystery eggs! Hatch them!

Cons:
Nightmare/Mixmode is not up.
Hardcore I heard is permadeath, may be fun for daredevils but I'm already having trouble finding gears.
Can't open your own shop or decorate your own tavern.
Can only see games opened by people in your tavern.
Can't see people selling items.
Can't switch characters in survival to level yourself.
Playverse gets confusing and seems pointless besides the party system. Should've just used steam to add buddies.
Aquanos has a glitchy area where the wyverns or flying eels circle around and not enter map.
Summoners now are just DPS pet" users
date: something that I feel a hunter should be having. A strong pet.\nSummoner's archers stay slow and weak
recommended: can't even pass easy mode deeper well solo when starting.\nNot sure how some people are doing 5mil dps already with 3 full level 60's geared up on first week

reviewText: The original Dungeon Defenders is a complete game with tons of content, 4 player split screen co op, full controllers support, mod support that allows for removal of player cap and new levels. I can't help but look at Dungeon Defenders Eternity as a downgrade. I think the right way to look at this game is this. If you really want to play this game online get this version. If you would rather have a more complete game, get the original. There are a lot of upsides to this addition, but it comes at a price. It also does not run as smoothly, so if computer specs are an issue pick up the first one instead. While I would like to imagine they would fix things up and do right by their community, they seem to be charging forward forgetting what got them here in the first place. It is extremely important to improve upon your game without sacrificing what people liked about it.

reviewText:
How do you make a game worse than it used to be ?
Well for starters, you put a game client so Steam can't update the game.
Then, you directly put the players in a public room, even if they wish to play by themselves.
And if you start a game that you supposedly host, you still need the servers to be online. Why ? Awful DRM of course. Because it worked so well on Diablo 3...

On top of that, the flaws of the original are still here (ie Floaty and unsatisfying combats, lack of proper tooltips, etc..)

Just don't buy this game. It's not worth your time or your money.

reviewText:
I used to have a thumbs up and a good recommendation for this game as the patches keep coming in, fixing issues and all. But sorry Trendy, you just destroyed your own game and its player base with Patch 3.4

1. Nerfed the hard work of people progressing deep into Insane content once
2. Nerfed the hard work of people progressing deep into Insane content AGAIN (After declaring to players that Patch 3.3 addressed all nerf issues, Trendy went ahead to nerf AGAIN in Patch 3.4 without an official announcement)
3. Nerfed the drops of Insane content itself. (Particularly Akatiti Insane, and this is not in the patch notes)

Very very bad job from you both at Nom Nom Games and Trendy, honestly disappointed with the unannounced nerfs and Trendy not being transparent with your players.

reviewText:
After playing this game for 1,5 months of chance I ust admit I've lost confidence in it. Let me summarize why:

- intensive serverside lag issues to a degree that the server makes enemies do impossible moves, eventually causing you to loose matches.
- So called balancing. Way to much of the abilities and defense units have are subpar towards the enemies. The few exceptions get nerfed so instead of a Tower/RPG hybrid they changed this game into a FPS clone.
- Mistakes they made in the previous installment made again. In the previous game some loot was to powerfull so they made it far more difficult to obtain. Causing new players to never achieve the levels the first players got into. In this game they admitted some loot dropped that shouldn't have. They stopped the loot from appear and nerfed peoples loot to a degree that should have dropped with a boss who shouldn't be defeatable (people used a glitch to kill him cheap). But this gear still had stats you would find 1 in million in current drops. Now they added a new difficulty with monsters finetuned to those stats on gear. So people who played legitly have no chance of winning this causing another gap between players. It also confirms in this game only cheating gets you further in the game.
- Very bad menu's. In the more difficult levels even one second not paying attention could cause you to loose the game. But any action in the menu's takes at least 5 seconds to animate. We don't live in the later 80's anymore where 256 colorsreens were high tech on a 286 model. Get your junk together and show me computers can calculate faster then humans can.
- Poor fixing in forgotten" content and disriminating people because of it: Some special gun gifted to you when you bought the game wasn't available in the first weeks. They fixed it so who buys the game now does get it. The only way for the players who bought the game earlier to get this gun is to create an account on their forums and PM the community managar there and hope he posts you a code to get the gun in game. No news post IN the game mentions this so any player who isn't active on the forum doesn't know about this and doesn't get the gun he should have gotten in the first place. If it was forum visiters only I'm ok with it but as newer players do get it now without touching the forums ever. It's downright discriminative.
- Bad community. Those cheaters with their over the top gear are whining the game is to easy. And it seems the developers are listening to them.

So after seein al that I can only see the game going down the never ending spiral of not letting any new player enjoy their game. as the excisting community is rotten I don't want to touch this piece of #### ever again. Can't wait for Dungeon Defenders 2 so I can give it negative points as well. As this team is not learning from their earlier mistakes

reviewText: dde is marketed as the Definitive" DD experience. After having played thousands of hrs. of DD I had high hopes for dde. Sadly it is just too radical a departure from what captivated me in the original game. It is an action RPG tower defense game like the original that has the same char. with diff. abilities and balancing. Many of the mechanics and much of the gameplay style is changed for the sake of making the game play like what I'm assuming dd2 will be like instead of staying with the tried and true of what DD did right and fixing issues and refining what worked there. It is saved server side so it requires a constant internet connection as well and suffers from lag routinely due to this fact. Some like it due to the fact there is less a problem with hackers but for me it is not enough to make or keep me playing it I will stick to the original."

reviewText:
Okay, before I go into details (this will mainly compare it with the original): is the game still fun with friends? Yes.
This remake/redo/whatever did improve and balance the gameplay, which was definitely needed. That is one major positive.

However, it threw away so many of the basic elements that made the original a great game. I am unable to stay in the same lobby with my friends between matches, instead it boots them to some random server. The original had it great, keeping us all in the same place, instead of making me reinvite and reconnect every time we start or fail a map/tavern.
By the same token, because the servers are now externally hosted (I understand - helps control hacking), my ping is so much higher. This isn't such a bad issue when there are not too many monsters, but later on, it is a real pain.
The microtransactions, well I don't really care too much about them: they're mainly just for taunts, which are not needed.
However the shop is so much less intuitive and instead of making everything easier, it became much the opposite. It tried to improve on sorting, which is good, but it still fails to have a filter for a certain type of armor. Considering you get set bonuses, it would be better to have this.
Also you don't get the bonuses from two weapons, instead everytime you swap your weapons, your towers get the current weapon's stats. This is fine for balance, except everytime I press z" to swap weapons
date: my towers are half damaged. It would be easier just to have the one weapon so I can easily replace it when I get better ones
recommended: or have an option to have 1 or 2.\n\nYeah
hoursPlayed: just my rant.\n\nTL;DR : Gameplay - Good
voteText: Everything else - Kinda disappointing."

reviewText:
As an avid fan of the original, I was looking forward to a rebalanced Dungeon Defenders with additional content and all the selling points that made DD Eternity sound so appealing.

Do not buy this game.

Other reviews have said that most issues have been fixed, and I don't know if that's true. What I do know is that the client is garbage. If you live anywhere other than the US, your latency will be unbearable. The game data can be downloaded rather than streamed, but the download speed is atrocious. Hosting game fails more often than it succeeds. I won't say this game is a cash grab, or done maliciously. I think they just did an absolutely horrible job implementing the fixes and content they had planned for this game.

Massive, unplayable disappointment.

reviewText:
Okay, so I've gotten down about 50 hours or so of casual play on the old DD. It was frustrating at times, but rewarding I feel when everything went as planned. Now we come to this. I read on the store page that it's somehow better and balanced and stuff. I'm like...sure, the game had a few things here and there that could have been taken care of. So might as well take it and give it a go.

Weeeeeellllllp, even with the discount that was I managed to get it, it's still a very dissapointing experience.

The graphics are better I admit, they look pretty awesome too. The item mods that appear on you are a nice addition too and you can color them with dyes as well, which is even more awesome.

Aaand that would conclude my pro's for it. The neutral stuff, is well it's just the same deal, which isn't really bad in my opninion but take it as you may in the end, as everyone has their own feelings about that.

And the cons? well, there are quite a few in my case.
1. Look I understand a downloader and installer on the same launcher that does both things at the same time. Though, pray tell me why dit it feel like warming up my proccessor during that, I have no problems with heating when steam downloads other games.

2. FFS can you all just take some time to add some more ♥♥♥♥ing video options? The classic DD had ♥♥♥♥ for options ingame, and just a few basic things in it's launcher. I personally dont own a high end machine, and being able to remove certain details" would improve my performance. And dont get me started on the "OOOH BUT IT TAKES AWAY FROM THE EXPERIENCE"....Look the last thing I care about when building ♥♥♥♥ and fighting crap is how nice and surreal the shading looks okay? and in my case it's just taxing my CPU and such.

3. WHAT THE ACTUAL ♥♥♥♥? The first time you enter you are placed in a tavern full of random players
date: faaar away from the feel of the nice and cozy private one you had in the last game. Figuring out how to do stuff is just a chore and there's no tutorials that I could find ingame to explain ♥♥♥♥ to me as some things are different than the last game. Also can you ♥♥♥♥ing clean up the ingame store? I nearly bought stuff for real cash
hoursPlayed: and like someone else said
voteText: somehow it's even more of a mess than the old inventory/box/shop thing.\n\n4. Is this a game coded for mobile platforms and ported to PC? It barely feels optimized

reviewText:

Pros : Starting over is pretty fun.
New maps
All characters unlocked.
Skins provided.
Tavern with other players! Can shout for party invites.
Items now show! Stylists would love this feature.
More item slots!
Coins and consumables! Amulets to help you.

Cons:

Can't open your own shop or decorate your own tavern.
Can only see games opened by people in your tavern.
Can't see people selling items.
Can't switch characters in survival to level yourself.
Playverse gets confusing and seems pointless besides the party system. Should've just used steam to add buddies.

reviewText:
My first experience almost made me want to rage quit the game. You click play and you're dumped into a tavern with 20 other people. WTF? Then I go look for a way to get my friends in. Eh... nope. Escape-menu? Nothing. After 20 minutes of Googling, I finally found that if either press F11 or go to a menu where you get a mouse cursor, and then click the icon in the top-right that looks like a ball of wool, you'll get a sidebar menu that looks worse than Games for Windows Live. Seriously, it's horrendous. But, this is the thing you have to use to add friends to your friends list (because you can't invite Steam friends straight into a game, like with Dungeon Defenders 1), and then you need to form a party using friends from your friends list. Only then can you start a game with your friends.

The gameplay so far has redeemed the poor user experience with the friends list. All classes from DD1 are there, though they have been altered a bit. The summoner no longer has its own unit count, but shares defense points with the rest. You can still equip two pets like before. Pets also grant you a special ability, which you can activate with the X key and which has a short recharge timer. There are a few more gear slots and item sets are now clearly indicated. There are consumables which give you more options while you play, such as regeneration amulets or taunt-totems.

Loot is now assigned to each player, like in Diablo III. This is also the case for mana from treasure chests. So everything you see on the ground, you can pick up!

They introduced coins as a currency for in the shop and for upgrading items. I suppose this is to make a distinction between the stuff you use to build towers and what you use to enhance your characters. So far it feels right.

TL;DR; Social features are messed up. Remember: open a menu (Escape or i) then ball of wool in the top-right corner. Besides that, it's a decent game that looks to be an improvement over DD1.

reviewText:
If this is the way DDII is heading then I'm not optimistic about the future.

Always online and no single player; microtransaction store; horrible texture streaming (so you need to wait five minutes for the graphic fidelity to reach the level of the original game) and no capacity to import existing characters.

They've made some tweaks and rebalances to the gameplay, but not to a noticeable extent. Perhaps this will find it's market on mobile devices, but for the PC it's inferior to the original in every way.

About the only good thing I can say here is that it made me start playing the original Dungeon Defenders again.

reviewText:
This really should have gone through a prerelease beta phase. For some reason, Trendy decided that it would be a great idea to rip out and try to replace the (quite functional and pleasant to use) existing UI from DD1 and replace it with this mess. I had to look up the manual to create a hero, the one thing you have to do before even getting into the tavern! And once you're there, it just gets worse. You're in a tavern with a zillion random people, with no way to get into one with the friends you want to play with.

The old crystal customization is gone, and there's no way, as far as I can tell, to change your skin color, only hair and clothing. A few of the old seasonal and challenge missions didn't make it over, either.

Overall, I'd recommend the original version, if you can get it on sale. It seems to have slightly better performance, and the features it has, like split-screen, are more interesting to me than what DDE has. If you like to play with randoms, though, DDE might be a better choice.

reviewText:
PRO:
* no more hacked items , secure server. that is not to be taken lightly , the old game was full of hacked gear
and uber characters that would just steamroll the content.

CONS:
* game feels a little bit clucky , the load on demand is a bit annoying , and searching for a group
often gets stuck for me (have to restart the game then)
* waiting timer to start a private match .. why ?
* no offline play , which didnt really bother me . the original game i only played online so meh.
* no private tavern .. i liked that you had a personal space with your trophies on display and where you could test your dps without a gaziilion other people pushing in.
* when searching for a game , its not really clear what game modes are listed. i accidently entered an insane
level at lvl 1 :s . get rid of the fancy mode icons and just use text .
* every now and then the server stop responding . finished a few games and was unable to return to the lobby , couldnt join games etc..

overall , for 6$ , why not . its decent worth for the cost , played 10h so far and enjoying it even
with the technical difficulties.

reviewText:
For old dd fans out there. Take care when purchasing this. I havent played it long. But I have 100's of hours in the original dd.

Let me start out with the tavern. Which is now a bunch of whiney kids complaining about everything and everyone spamming the ♥♥♥♥ out of everyone. Annoying.

Second. Liked a ranged character? Have fun trying to actually hit things because even if you marker indicates that you can hit your target. It will just shoot past it. Even if you're standing POINT BLANK in front of your enemies. Dumb.

Second. The UI and all the screens got so confusing. Its over-detailed and not needed. The old interface served it much better. But this is a personal opinion.

I found the game to be less responsive aswell. Slower responses to quickkeys for building etc.

The graphics are much better. But thats about it.

If you like dd. Stick with that version. This one is ATM not worth it. This needs alot of work before it can be considered close to the original.

reviewText:
Dugeon Defender fans don't buy this garbage.

This 'dlc' ruins the dungeon defender experience. It forces you to always be in an online game with other random people. Not only that, but because of this new log-in system, I have lost all my characters and their gear. You too will lose all your fond memories and your menu screens as well. With the new, always on-line system, there is no need for menu screens for customizing your crystal and such. Trendy Entertainment erased hours of my life because /some/ people cheated their game and they felt it ruined the experience for others.  Well now my experience was ruined by Trendy Entertainment.

For shame Trendy Enterainment; This is not how Dungeon Defenders was meant to be played. You got it right the first time.

reviewText:
Microtransactions have no place in paid games.  The fact that they're there leads me to believe that this game is set to go F2P in the future - after they've made as much as they can off sales.  I refuse to play this game until the cash shop has been removed.

I was one of the silly people to buy this game when it was first released, belieiving that it was a finished product instead of the Early Access title that it really is.  When I was told of the microtransaction shop right after i bought it and all the severe game-breaking bugs in it, i was furious.

Little or no response was given by the devs other than this being a test bench for Dungeon Defenders 2 (which I've been told it will be a F2P game) - yet all the information I've found on the next Nom Nom/Trendy game to come out has led me to a non-Dungeon Defenders game that looks like it's graphically and engine-wise identical.  It's a game called Monster Madness.

I honestly feel I've been scammed.

If you too feel this game should have been labeled and had and EARLY ACCESS warning to it, you should write Steam Support and ask for a refund.  If enough people do this, the game will get yanked until they get things fixed or an Early Access put on it and a warning that it has Microtransactions ingame.

Look familiar?
https://search.yahoo.com/search;_ylt=AuLfd33JnfzCsxph8UEsyimbvZx4

reviewText:

reviewText:
I was a big fan of original Dungeon Defenders. Played it too many hours. So I might say I know what I want from DD game.

Let's keep this simple, DDE couldn't be done as an update to original game. There are too many changes. Most of all new online only. Old game was ridded by hackers. Financial side is awful. Mana was worth nothing in trading. Now with DDE, everything starts from beginning. Perhaps keeps hackers out for good.

Now pros & cons:

Pros
-New loot, more sets and cosmetic changes
-Full wipe, game really needed it
-New maps, haven't yet tried many, still.
-Pet hatching
-Control over hotkeys. So good system now, you can remap num keys for different characters way you need/like.
-New survival system. I have just scratched surface, tried Deeper Well at medium difficulty, survived about 20 minutes with level 14 character.
-I don't mind the new inventory. Make folders ;) I personally made folders for armor, weapons, pets etc. Inside armors I made folders Old School and New School where I put old armor and new ones.
-Maybe even more stuff I haven't yet tried or discovered :P
-Always online, no more hackers.

Cons
-Always online. One thing that bugs me, we should get personal taverns. As I organise my inventory, almost everytime peep joins or leaves, dragged item drops.. And too much hazzle. Need some privacy :D
-Possibility of downtimes on servers.
-I'd like to have everything integrated at steam. Another account at Playverse.. Oh well, just have to live with it.

I recommend this game upgrade for old and new players. For missing LAN support, what kind of LAN party is it if there's no good internet connection? :)

reviewText: I have only played a small amount of this game compared to the 300+ hours I put into the original game but still easy to compare the two. I would recommend this game to anyone who doesn’t own the first one. The first question I asked when playing this game is it better than the original, I would say no it is not. They made some good improvements to the game but they left out of the things I liked about the old. The graphics are better and the game itself seems to run fairly smooth. I do like the fact that they made changes to the currency which a lot better than the mana crap from the first game. I'm still up in the air about the gear changes, while it’s nice to have my character appearance change with the gear, about 50% of the time gear looks really stupid when you have it all on. I wish they would just let me toggle the gear appearance on or off like other games instead of making buy items to make them invisible. I have never been a fan of having to connect online all the time to play a game. When it works it’s not a problem but I get a lot of random lag spikes in this game even when doing a private session, which I would never see in the first when hosting my own game. The whole time I play this game it makes me just want to go back and play the original, I want to like this game as much as the other one but just not as good. While this game does feel less slapped together as it did when it was released it still missing something, not sure what that is. Even with the problems I have with this game it still can be really fun, if you have never played the original this is a good game to get into the franchise.

reviewText:
Played it for about four hours, I'd tell you hold off for now.  If you're one of those that purchased the original and are curious to what an alpha version of DD2 is, then you can satisfy your curiosity at a cost of your fast food breakfast.  Even with the rushed out single player, there is still more work to be done.  Trendy was very shady with this release.

The game plays very much the same as its predecessor except no way to set up co-op between your friends outside of connecting to a public lobby to do so (as far as I am aware of this posting) which makes creating games that much more difficult.  If it is possible the current layout of the game is confusing and far from intuitive.  People that were used to controller play more than keyboard play will find themselves at a loss and trying to at least remap what they can do with their controller.  There's very little in the way of that support in this iteration which may perhaps be a sign for DD2.

Disappointed that this isn't tagged alpha or early access.  This is in no way a finished product.

reviewText:
UPSIDES:
Take everything good from the original Dungeon Defenders, scrape off the awful barnacles known as 'lag', 'hackers', and 'a totally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t endgame', and re-release it for a fraction of the cost with all the DLC pre-added. Now slap on a ton of new gear and cosmetic options, a VASTLY improved economy, a ton of new powers and systems, and a better online play system than TrendyNet ever was. You've got a good idea what's going to come out of DDE then.

DOWNSIDES:
-- A new (optional) streaming texture" system makes the game look pretty assy for a while after each patch

reviewText:
As others have mentioned in their negative reviews, this game stinks like a mobile app ported to PC.

No real single player, just private matches online which friends can still join even if not desired. No private tavern. Poor matchmaking instead of server listings. Microtransactions. Streamed game files instead of locally stored content. No offline mode. No content creation tools.

If you want to play DD, play the original. Pass this by. The few new maps do not counter all the other poor decisions made in this game's development.

reviewText:
DON'T BUY IT.....YET

I will change my review when it is fixed but I am gonna give it a fortnight before i bother ltrying again

The new features are fun and the two new maps I have played so far are cool, but there are some serious design and installation issues;

The install resets everytime you reopen the game and 90% of the time it fails to create a game session from the tavern (even a private game session).  This makes it pretty much unplayable most of the time.  I have tried reinstalling and deleting my data several times with no luck.

But when it does work, these design issues bring the game down;

*A lack of a private tavern, which leads to a stuffed tavern where you have to climb over everyone else.

*After EVERY game you have to go back to this tavern, and when you play a new match you have to wait 35 seconds for the   lobby countdown, even if you are on your own.

*There is no restart button so if you botch a set up its back to the tavern and several minutes of loading.

*The new inventory system is VERY confusing, why can't we just have the old one ?

*The Report a Bug" button crashes the game

************THIS ISN'T A PROBLEM FOR ME PERSONALLY BUT EVERYONE SHOULD KNOW

reviewText: As a big fan of the original run of the game I was curious to try this one out. (Hooray for cheap deals!) I was just utterly floored about this version once I got going with it. Playing solo is all fine and dandy but you only get 20 mana per chest! It forces you to rethink how you build things right out of the gate. The game itself chugs pretty harshly even with things turned way down. Not to mention the gameplay itself feels sluggish and slow. The tavern is such a cluster of stuff going on and generally lags even moreso! The biggest gripe I have is I always enjoyed going from mission to mission but now you have to go back to the tavern after each one.\n\nStick with the original Dungeon Defenders, it's a faaaar superior version than this load. I hope to god Dungeon Defenders 2 isn't modeled after this version because I will not buy it.

reviewText:
TL;DR: It's a new and overall great perspective on a familiar game many love, with it's issues, but it is an overall welcome addition to the Dungeon Defenders series.

Longer review:
I absolutely loved Dungeon Defenders 1. They got a lot of things right, and all into one accessible game. Now Dungeon Defenders Eternity came out, keeping in mind a lot of the issues that were in the original Dungeon Defenders.

They have largely smashed the hacker issue, due to server-side items. This requires an online connection, and I'm more than happy with that in return for limiting hackers.

They have have several notable changes to the class mechanics, some major, and some even controversial. In my view, the way to look at this is... this is not DD1. This is a familiar game, with a new perspective. Are the changes for the best? That's a matter of opinion. Personally, I find the changes refreshing.

They added on several new game mechanics, and fixed some annoying issues from DD1. Did they get every change right? Probably not. But overall, this is a new take on DD1 that I find a new great twist to a familiar game, and worth the one-time price tag for a still awesome game that now comes with much of the previous DLC content right along with the base game.

In the end, even with issues considered, I would certainly recommend this, what is in my opinion a wonderful game, to others.
voteText: 6 of 13 people (46%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
DDE might look like a good deal since it includes most of the original game's DLC. It's not.

The bad:
- Playverse is a laggy, randomly disconnecting mess
- Client is unstable, crash to desktop is common
- Upgrades on the ground immediately disappear before you can run over to pick them up thanks to a low items on ground cap.
- Towers somehow got dumber from the original, big damage tower like Striker now shoots the weak goblin in the front of a pack instead of the super tough ogre in the middle.
- 'Noone' plays this, thanks to all the other issues, see http://steamcharts.com/search/?q=Dungeon+Defenders for details.

The good:
- Includes vast majority of the dlc available in the original for free.
- Can be played in offline mode which gets rid of the lag but of course its rather lonely.

reviewText:
Pro's:
Anti-hacking with server side storage of your characters and equipment. The old game was way too easy to hack, and most people did it.
New maps that where not in the original game.

Cons:
LOADS of lag spikes that are more likely to kill you than the mobs.
Internet connection is required at all times.
NO Splitscreen mode (they are talking about maybe bringing it back in some way on the forums).
No Nightmare mode yet.
No PvP mode yet.
No Hardcore mode yet.
No private taverns. Publicly shared with random players.
Missing maps and challenges compared to the original game.
Game hangs on loading screens.
No player-kick system
A lot of leeching players in maps. (perhaps there will be a way to prefend this, discussion on forums)

For a more in depth comparison with the original game see the guide  here

reviewText: Finally Trendy fixes all the issues with the original Dungeon Defenders and adds in cross platform support.  New levels, with all the best levels and campaign missions from the first one, tied together in perfect harmony.  Hackers are gone, kick-abuse is gone, which were the reasons that most people stopped playing the first game.  It's true that this support should have just been added to the original, and I'm not sure the reasons behind why it wasn't, but for the introductory price it was hard to say no.  Playverse isn't the best online platform support but neither was steam when it first came out, and I have faith Trendy will fix it up in no time.  Plus PV makes it super easy for friends to join in your game by prompting them to accept/decline games you're hosting and automatically placing you into the same party system you've used before.  It's like if XBOX live auto added you to party chat with your friends that were online and auto joined their games when you turned on your xbox, it's that easy.  For $6 (introductory price + DD owners discount) these improvements is a definite recommend.  I ended up buying a 2nd copy for the wife's account to play co-op.

reviewText:
I own the original Dungeon Defenders and saw very little reason to purchase this game.  However, the Linux client for the original Dungeon Defenders is full of bugs and Trendy seems to have no intention of fixing them.  Meanwhile, the Windows version, while exhibiting a bug or two, is far more stable and contains fewer obvious problems.  Since I read that this game was web based and Trendy advertises that it supported Linux right out of the gate, I figured that even if there were problems, all platforms would be on the same footing.  Boy, was I wrong.

I can't say that on Linux there are some strange effects, or that this class' towers don't work correctly, or that performance is poor.  I can't say that because the Linux client WON'T START AT ALL!  THE CLIENT JUST CRASHES!  I CAN'T EVEN PLAY THE GAME!

I've gone through forum post after forum post, looking for a solution or maybe that  it just doesn't work on my distro (Fedora 20).  But it turns out the problem doesn't not appear to be distro specific.  The client just doesn't work on any Linux distro.  What's worse is that Trendy appears to know this but still lists the game as being available for Linux.

Now you might think I'm just a flamer and that if what I've said here is true then there would be far more negative reviews by Linux gamers.  Here's the catch (and I hope you're sitting down for this one):

VALVE WILL NOT LET YOU POST A REVIEW UNLESS YOU'VE PLAYED THE GAME FOR AT LEAST 5 MINUTES!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Not the easiest thing to do if the game won't run for more than a second.  What I had to do was install Steam on a Windows system, login, install the game on that system, then let it run for 5+ minutes.  All just so I would be allowed to post this review!  I was so disgusted, I didn't even actually play the game on Windows.  I just let the launcher sit there.

Now I understand Valve's point of view, trying to slow down trolls as best they can.  However, in this case, they have to know by now that there is a major problem with the Linux client to this game.  Yet they still allow the game to be listed as Available on Linux".  That makes them partially negligent in allowing this fraud to continue.

Since I can't get my money back for this game
date:
I'll give any reader patient enough to read to the end of my rant this advice:  Don't give Trendy a dime of your money for this POS until they get their act together and actually deliver what they promised!


************** UPDATE 10/10/2014 *****************

It looks like they've made some updates to the Linux client.  You have 4 options to launch now (not sure what they all mean).  The options are "Play Dungeon Defenders Eternity"
hoursPlayed: "Unlink Steam Libraries"
voteText: "Play Offline".  For me they all do the same thing.  The application tries to launch and exits.  I get a flash of a window
helpfulPercent: but it's disappears so quickly I can't see anything to give me a useful hint as to what's going on.\n\nTrendy (or whomever is developing this now)
votesHelpful: you guys suck!!!"

reviewText:
The game feels like it should have gotten an early access label.

It's barely playable most of the time, I kept getting stuck in place due to horrific lag [connection, not computer] (even in private/solo matches).  Because of this I can't finish a match because it is impossible to protect against the enemies due to not being able to get to them (and because I can't move to place towers).

The public tavern causes nothing but issues.  I can barely manage my inventory because of how confusing the UI is.  There is no tutorial for people who are trying it for the first time (even as an experience DD1 player I barely knew what was happening on my screen)

The new features" don't really make the game worth paying for if you already own DD1 and basically any of the DLC.

I plan to come back to this game after each update to see if any of the problems are fixed.

Most importantly
date: it is not playable for those without a good internet connection "offline" play doesn't work (I'm not even sure it actually exists)
recommended: and private matches are still incredibly laggy (even with 30Mb/s+ speeds)\n\nMy reccomendation to all who read this is:  Give the game a while before you buy it.  Once you see the reviews skew away from 90% negative (wait for at least 60%) then maybe give it a shot."

Just a heads up you have to make a playverse account to play.

When you first boot the game on your steam account the first time after you buy it, make sure you make an account.  If someone else logs on your steam copy before you do, you'll be logging in as them every time you lauch the game.  You'll also have to contact support and be unable to make your own account until they get to you.  Thats what happened to me when I had a friend log in to start the patching process :(

It took them about a week to get to my email, but once they did they fixed it pretty quick.

reviewText:
Did you like the original Dungeon Defenders game?
Do you primarily use a desktop computer to game?
If so, then steer clear of this shoddy re-release!

Although the development team claims that this is primarily a PC game, the game itself claims otherwise. With shoddier controls, a forced always-online multiplayer tavern, mantdatory waiting period before starting a match (even a private match), and a new 'playverse' interface which feels optimized for touchscreens (likely because it was), this re-release seems to offer very little in the way of enhanced content over the original title.

The good:
-You can stream the game's levels as you need them
-New item types & revamped stats
-You can play the game on your iphone & your android & your pc & probably your OUYA too

The bad:
-Touchscreen interface is clunky when using a mouse or gamepad
-Character management is horrid
-Character skins were converted to items, cluttering your stash with needless junk
-Always-online means you need 100% connectivity to play even singleplayer
-80% of the options are gone, such as replaying a level without going back to the tavern

Final thoughts:
Maybe this game will get better before release, but I doubt it. These issues are part of their cross-platform design experience.

2/10, buy the original instead.

EDIT: Changed my rating from 4/10 to 2/10 on my discovery that if you lose internet connection for even half a second, your session is terminated. In singleplayer. Yup.
