column23: which are permanent stat boosters
column24: but these artifacts are not stackable and offer completely negligible increases (we're talking adding 8hps to a character with 10-20k life
column25: and 1-2 to fire resist when you have 950).\n6) Loot despawning priorities - In DD1
column26: loot has prioritization on what disappears first.  In DDE
column27: it doesn't.  And there's FAR fewer items allowed on the ground (online server reasons?).  Currently
column28: instead of the ~200 items allowed in DD1 on bigger maps
column30: and because there's no loot despawn prioritization
column31: that means stuff often disappears before it hits the ground.  Loot only appears near you
column32: and even when it does that upgrade that just dropped might disappear before you can get to it while the 50g item you can buy from the tavernkeeper sticks around for 10 minutes.\n7) Meaningful progression and incentive to do hard maps - Everyone does insane ramparts.  Why?  Because it drops far better loot than any of the DLC or later maps like CD
column33: and it's one of the easiest maps in the game.  Of course
column34: this means that once you get the gear from ramparts
column36: so the playerbase has dropped by half every 1.5-2 weeks since release.\n8) Tower/Character balance - DD1 didn't have great balance
column37: but it at least didn't have completely broken classes.  Huntress traps are so bad that no one uses them
column38: summoner pets are broken (either useless or so OP they break their own animation with how fast they shoot)
column39: towers get over-nerfed for no reason and in an odd manner (including nerfs to huntress traps no one uses)
column40: and some classes are flat-out bad now (barbarian is HORRIBLE).\n9) Itemization - Some great items from DD1 are missing (treadmill pets
column43: and the itemization in general is just inferior.  Weapons are all very similar and no longer have speed stats
column44: so they all basically feel the same (outside of huntress
column45: who has a few weps that are clearly superior
column46: especially with the removal of speed stats).  Monk weapons all have horrible ranged damage so ranged monk dps isn't viable
column47: barbarian swords are junk (speed stat issue again causing problems
column48: to say nothing of barbarian stat scaling itself)
column49: apprentice weapons are all similar and junky enough that apprentice DPS isn't really a thing
column50: etc.\n10) Rewards for the challenges/campaign maps/survivals - There's no rewards for any of these
column51: including beating CD.  You get... nothing.  no seahorses
column53: no specific weapons dropping from specific bosses... nothing unique.  everything that drops drops everywhere
column54: and while some campaign maps like aquanos will reward you after beating a boss
column55: the rewards are completely random... you can get a few accessories and nothing else.\n11) A whole MESS of maps
column59: and other fun things that simply don't exist in DDE.  Too many to count or list here.\n12) a workable armor set system - DDE has a few extra slots for armor and 9 different sets instead of 4.  I'm too lazy to do the math
column60: but instead of sets being fairly viable for everyone
column62: they're now basically inaccessible to most of the community
column63: since the chances of you having the same 1 (out of 9) type of item for all 7 slots that's decent enough to wear is nigh impossible.\n13) A balanced upgrading system - The new system is percentage-based
column64: and it's FAR harder to get money for those upgrades.  You'll have to spend a LOT of time playing Vacuum Simulator
column65: since smashing the "E" key and picking up everything to sell it later is the only decent way to get money.  But even that aside
column66: the percentage-based system (10% of base stats per upgrade
column67: and 20% of base damage per) completely breaks itemization.  I won't go into detail
column68: but suffice to say this breaks endgame items and throws items (and thus
column69: characters) completely out of balance.\n14) Kick system - If you like playing public games
column70: accept that about half the players you encounter will simply afk the second they join the game
column71: and there's nothing you can do about it.  At all.  And that's if you're lucky... if you're not they can actively ruin your experience by selling your towers
column73: there's nothing you can do about it.\n\nBasically

column80: but here's what it all boils down to:  you are NOT getting a definitive version of DDE.  You're buying what everyone playing agrees is a beta product.  I didn't even list out the major bugs & exploits in the game

column83: none of it is balanced yet and there's so many bugs and issues in the game that you shouldn't give Trendy money for a "definitive edition" when it's nowhere near that state.  Some people might still like the game and play it

reviewText:
Did you like the original Dungeon Defenders game?
Do you primarily use a desktop computer to game?
If so, then steer clear of this shoddy re-release!

Although the development team claims that this is primarily a PC game, the game itself claims otherwise. With shoddier controls, a forced always-online multiplayer tavern, mantdatory waiting period before starting a match (even a private match), and a new 'playverse' interface which feels optimized for touchscreens (likely because it was), this re-release seems to offer very little in the way of enhanced content over the original title.

The good:
-You can stream the game's levels as you need them
-New item types & revamped stats
-You can play the game on your iphone & your android & your pc & probably your OUYA too

The bad:
-Touchscreen interface is clunky when using a mouse or gamepad
-Character management is horrid
-Character skins were converted to items, cluttering your stash with needless junk
-Always-online means you need 100% connectivity to play even singleplayer
-80% of the options are gone, such as replaying a level without going back to the tavern

Final thoughts:
Maybe this game will get better before release, but I doubt it. These issues are part of their cross-platform design experience.

2/10, buy the original instead.

EDIT: Changed my rating from 4/10 to 2/10 on my discovery that if you lose internet connection for even half a second, your session is terminated. In singleplayer. Yup.

reviewText:
As someone who didnt really play the origional DD much but saw it was cheap, I picked up the game for like £5 on some super special offer. I have enjoyed the game thus far but have mostly played with 2 or more friends from other games. It is very addictive and almost everything but the character emotes are free.

Honestly it's a game that if you have friends to play it with and like a more interactive tower defence game then you should definitely play this. I would recommend once you buy it and DL it, load it up and let it download all the maps before you play. This prevents any issues when loading maps and minimizes bugs.

It's true, this does seem like their BETA test for a Dungeon Defenders 2, making Eternity more like a 1.5 version that the makers can milk ££ out of...and I am completely fine with that. I would rather buy this game cheap while it's buggy and report the bugs than DD2 which will hopefully be awesome be this precarious. The ingame UI needs a LOT of work, and I mean a lot. I didn't find it user friendly but this is hopefully something being worked on. Notably the UI does allow access to Twitch for easy streaming - like streaming a BETA. Oh, I see what you did there game makers. *wink wink*.

A mixed bag from me, but I'm still gonna keep playing. If they release nightmare mode or boost the lvl cap from 60 i'll probably play more. I also like what they've done to survival mode making it a 1:00:00 hour constant defence where you don't have to AFK for 12 hours until good loot starts to drop :D!

reviewText:
Complete copy/paste of the original, with very few features added and more taken away. It appears to be an Android port that hardly lives up to the depth and quality of the first game. Several bugs and missing features as of release, to name a few:

-No Nightmare mode.
-No Hardcore mode.
-No Mixed mode.
-Miscoded item/item levels that have been retroactively nerfed and players not appropriately compensated
-New survival mode, 1 hour of endless waves, no character swapping, extremely poor loot, disappearing items issues worse than DD1.
-Desynch/lag issues.
-Required Playverse launcher.
-No single player/offline mode.
-No Private Tavern.
-Microtransaction Market added.
*-Many players losing characters/loot entirely.

If you want the real Dungeon Defenders experience, I strongly recommend trying the original, and avoid trading/using the hacked items that have spread like wildfire (single player would be ideal).

This game" is hardly worth $5.00 and should be marked as an Early Access/Alpha title or pulled from Steam. Falsely advertised and horribly unpolished
"

reviewText:
This is the first time I've ever reviewed a game, but I felt compelled to due to the blatantly false advertising for this one.  Far from the definitive version advertised, this is just a money grab.  A rebalanced endgame?  Endgame difficulty is currently dissabled with no eta on when it might be implemented.  Hardcore mode and Mix mode from DD1?  Disabled with no eta.  Remember running survivals in DD1 and running around at the end to see what gear dropped?  Well in DDE monsters drop 1g coins in addition to loot.  There is a 400 item limit for how many things can be on the ground, and coins take up most of this limit, resulting in most of the loot despawning whithin moments of dropping.  No eta on when this might be fixed.  The developers from Nom Nom Games (thats right, this isn't being produced by the same people that created DD1, it's just being marketed by them) are making all the same mistakes they the Trendy developers made in DD1 and the community is suffering from whiplash while the devs flail around trying to fix their mistakes.



This is essentially a beta to test the playverse archetecture for Dungeon Defenders 2.  If you never played DD1, you might enjoy it.  If you played through nightmare mode in DD1, spend your money elsewhere.

reviewText:
This game is like a Director's Cut or Definitive Edition of the original Dungeon Defenders.  It takes everything that was great about Dungeon Defenders and adds new features such as consumable items, permanent enhancements and reusable amulets.  There are several new maps and challenges, including what appears to be the start of a new campaign.

The Tavern has been converted to an open lobby with a personal trophy room at the back.  Survival Mode has been modified from the original 3-5 hour binge to a 1 hour timed single wave survival and the loot curve has been balanced for proper advancement.  Players will also find that all loot and chests are player instanced so you can loot all you want.

In the original Dungeon Defenders, mana was used to summon traps/towers and level up weapons.  A few changes to this system make it more friendly.  Mana is now only used to summon traps and towers.  Weapons are leveled using gold coins and pets have their own separate experience pool.

I would recommend that you buy this if you enjoyed the original Dungeon Defenders and are still interested in playing. If you have already burnt out of the original Dungeon Defenders this game will not offer much to keep your interest since the innovations added do not offset the lack of new content.

reviewText:
This review in a nutshell: Singleplayer was added, games now 500x better. Dont believe me?

You should. All the negative reviews on this page are before they added singleplayer in.

When you first log in, I will admit, its nuts. Have you ever been to a spawn town in a busy MMO, or gone to New York? Thats it. The tavern is a hub that EVERYONE uses. So, sometimes crazyness happens. But don't you worry, little girl, this is the only time your little loner side has to show like a sore thumb. Ignore the people. Go join A PRIVATE GAME. Dont join a public game if you dont want to join muilitplayer. BOOM! Your alone!

The gameplay hasn't really changed, other than you now get less mana. Or so it first seems... in singleplayer this doesn't really matter, but in muilitplayer, people used to NOT share chest, and made it so people couldn't even do anything because there was no mana to go around. They changed it so every player can open every chest. So, 3 people can touch the same chest and it wont go away for the forth person. So, every player gets the same amount of mana. Otherwise, in singleplayer, this change sucks, because your getting less mana.

The games pretty. Nuff said.

They added some new missons to the main campain. It will feel a bit fresh to older players.

The GUI, is uh... really, well ugly, acually. Its new. Does it feel rushed? Completely, acually. Its not something you can't get used to, mine you, but its odd.

Coustumes are now items, so only 1 person can wear them. Yea, it kinda sucks. You can see your armor though, so who knows what you'll look like in the end anyway.

2nd to last, the crafting system. Cool! At the time of this review I couldnt test it out, but I'm sure that i lets you dupe items for crafting ingredents you find on quests.

Finally, the shop system. Lots of people don't like the whole spending real money thing, but its only for cosmetics, so its okay. The new system goes like this. Instead of using mana, it uses coins, witch is found the same way mana is. Its a bit more rare, but you wont cry because you only got 5 peices in a run. The money can buy lots of new items that are consumed on use. These items do a varying amount of things, but an example is a mana collector. Place this bad boy down, and collects mana for you? Easy! Nice! Theres also mana potions, health potions, bombs, lots of awesome stuff.

So, yea buy this game. If you havn't bought dungeon defenders go buy this. Its worth it. If you have bought dungeon defenders, its up to you. Its a plunge your gonna have to take, but the new changes and others things I didnt take about in this review, You might be happy. Remember that you have a big discount because of you owning the game already.


Remember though, I'm a dude on the internet. I like DD a lot. I bought this game (before singleplayer) knowning it was bad. I bought it anyway, because I love DD. I'm not gonna make you use your wallet. (If you have it anymore after the steam summer sales!)

Oh, and all DLC carrys over. Nice!

If I write anything else, I'll start writing a novel. You get the idea. Check out more reviews, NOT THE ONES BEFORE SINGLEPLAYER, before you spent your money.

reviewText:
I personally like the game, but like others, are a bit jaded on the details of what is new or included. I'll break it down best I can.  The game is basicly a GotY edition of Dungeon Defenders, including the DLCs from the original, but also including changes and new levels.

New, but not really listed
Matchmaking - You share one tavern.  I assume it has a cap, so there are several taverns.  To those who never played the base game, the tavern is where you prep before going into a game, sell items, and can goof off.
You will be paired with like, leveled people.  You still get to choose what level and difficulty you choose to play on.

Loot Drops per Character - Your item drops in a game are yours.  You don't have to worry about someone taking an upgrade because of the matchmaking.

Streaming Client - Yes the game looks bad when you first load, as many reviews have said.  This is due to the game streaming textures and whatnot the first time you need them.  It only downloads once.  That's why the download for the game through steam is quite small.

What might annoy
Microtransaction - Everyones favorite thing to hate.  Currently (June 22, 2014), the game only has emotes as microtransaction items.  A bit overpriced, but they are cosmetic only.

No Tutorial - It just dumps you into a lobby, the tavern.  No character creation, no explaination of controls.  Ask in chat and someone will probably gladly point you in the right direction.

Playerverse instead of Steamworks - They decided to use their own matchmaking system, with its own friends list, party making and trade system.  The reason probably stems from cross-platform play with phones/tablets.  This can be seen as a good thing if you plan to play on your phone or tablet as well.

No private game - This shortcoming is already being fixed tonight; seems like an oversight by them.  I think they were hoping to have a bustling matchmaking system, instead of a bunch of private games.

No character transfer - You'll be starting at level 1 again.

Things I like so far
Tweaked Play - Pets now have abilities you can activate.  You'll find pet eggs you can hatch.  And there are items you can use in combat, like health potions and bombs, as well as buffs.  Also they added a dodge ability.


Despite my short list of what I liked, I really enjoyed the original, and look forward to leveling up and seeing how the end-game has changed.  For people who haven't played the original, this is the version to get.  If you have the original and are debating getting this one for the discounted price, look at the things I highlighted.  Comment on this review if you have questions or want clarity.

reviewText:
It seems this bears reiteration upon reiteration:

Disregard the majority (though never all) of the negative reviews and sentiments for Dungeon Defenders Eternity. The vast majority are based upon misunderstandings, misconceptions or factual errors, and are therefore inapplicable to the actual product.

Dungeon Defenders Eternity is NOT:

* A mobile port. It is based completely on Dungeon Defenders, with added code and assets. From whence this idea comes, I know not, as there is NOTHING to suggest mobile roots.
* Laden with IAP. The in-game shop ONLY sells cosmetic items, a standard not only of the genre (in as far as DD can be categorized), but a new paradigm for the games industry as a whole. And it is one of the most harmless and fair ways for developers to increase their profits (which is often not about quick cash grabs, but about staying in business and making new games, especially for indie developers).
* Visually downgraded. This fallacy is based on the new streaming texture mechanics, where textures are streamed upon first launch, thus allowing players to get into the game faster. That this would make 50+ reviewers believe that there has been a graphical downgrade only shows that customers will jump to conclusions within SECONDS, and never challenge the legitimacy of their own preconceptions, or double check their initial findings. I first launched Eternity on a 1 MBIT/S TETHERED SMARTPHONE CONNECTION, and the textures for the tavern loaded within one minute.
* More demanding than the original edition. The two Steam apps put almost the exact same strain on my processor, GPU, etc.

Dungeon Defenders Eternity IS:

* Significantly improved. The list of new features include manual dodging, a whole crafting system, consumables and spell amulets that provide entirely new powers in battle, pets that can be hatched and trained to fight with their own abilities in battle, visual armor upgrades, and a true hardcore mode.
* FINALLY hacker-safe. Hacked characters made the original almost entirely unplayable for anyone hoping for balance and even matches, as so many players had over-levelled or over-equipped hacked characters. (This is one of the primary arguments for always-online requirements for games with multiplayer modes, and proven very succintly in this case.)
* Rebalanced.
* Endowed with an entirely new loot system, as this was an oft-critizied part of the original.
* Equipped for true cross-platform play. Progress is already shared with the Android Tegra version, and iOS will receive the same later this year.
* Not designed to siphon money of old players, as all of us who own the original are offered to buy DDE for 5 euros.
* Linked to the upcoming sequel, with unlockables that will be available in Dungeon Defenders 2.

So, is this a good game? That depends on your sentiments regarding the original. An improvement? Oh, yes, in nearly every single way. The ultimate version of Dungeon Defenders 1? Very, very nearly so.

Could Trendy have launched this new version more smoothly and predicted some of this confusion and irritation? Probably (though after looking at the Steam store description and new page for the game, I find it hard to see any room for significant misunderstanding, or most of the misconceptions that surround the launch).

A worthy purchase? If you are a fan of the original, definitively. If you’ve never played Dungeon Defenders? Oh, gawds, yes!

reviewText:
It's DD1, with a few changes.  I played (according to Steam) 831 hours of DD1.  So I'd say I'm pretty familiar with it.  This is basically the same game with some tweaks.

I don't like the lack of offline mode, but I understand the reasoning.  It really is the only way to prevent cheating.

I do like the pets-from-eggs (and they seem to be a lot more common) and that pets have quality levels.  I haven't done any crafting, but I'm looking forward to that.  Hardcore/permadeath is an interesting way to add a little spice to existing levels, as well as provide better loot in them.  Being able to play from a browser is nice, for those times when you aren't at your gaming rig.  Cross-platform play is nice, too.  It means I can play on my nVidia Shield or my PC or my fiancee's old Macbook.  (To be fair, I probably could have Steam-streamed it anyhow to those, but not while someone was using the PC.)

I'll be looking forward to some UI improvements, though.  Inventory management is a pain.  Especially for comparing equipment.

Overall, I like it.  Especially with the discount for owners of the original.

reviewText: So there are plenty of negative reviews on how terrible this game is, where about 70% of the reviewers have around half an hour played. The game isn't any where near as bad as everyone says it is, and if you enjoyed the original game, you'll enjoy this one. The cash shop only sells $1 emotes and nothing else (at least as far as I have seen) and the servers were fine for the few hours I played yesterday. The game's a great buy if you loved the original but didn't buy all the DLC as it all comes included in this game, and while it might be a harder sell point for someone who already bought all the DLC, the few new features the game offers, and the promise of no hackers, is a decent reason to pick this version up, and if those don't sound like good enough reasons, then stick to the original.

reviewText:
There is very little wrong with this game. It looks and feels like the original version, and the control and responsiveness are fine. They will feel clunky because you're going to play with a slow character for the first time in years.

The public taverns are utterly painless, and remove the hassle of closing your game every time you want to look at your inventory. Nor will you need to politely decline the companionship of players 5 times your level while they hop around on the bar.

Everything else seems pretty much the same to me, though I don't doubt that those of you who've put in hundreds of hours will find changes to the math you'll find pleasing or not so pleasing. The biggest change I see is that you won't need to derp around the game listing, wondering if you belong within the weird level range of the various games that have been running for heaven knows how long. You quite literally press go and get dropped into a game seconds later with people around your level. It's honestly pretty nice.

As a side note, the numbers on the negative reviews here paint a picture of an angry little brigade putting in an hour or less before writing the game off on bugaboo grounds. There are serious reasons to find fault with this game - there always have been - but they certainly aren't in play here. These people are upset about specific disagreements they have with the direction the franchise has taken, NOT with the actual quality of the game.

reviewText:
The Good:
- Visible armor
- Active abilities for pets
- New abilities (for all classes) through an amulet mechanic
- Dodging mechanics
- Crafting mechanics (haven't really gotten into this yet; might be ♥♥♥♥)
- Pretty much the complete package of DD for a lower price than the original complete edition
- Balanced item pick ups / general progression
- New content

The Bad:
- Always online
- Taverns are public (read: you load in to taverns with other players)
- A second overlay/service with login needed (I really hate this for Steam games)
- The new UI is clunky as all hell
- Postprocessing somehow looks worse than the original (everything looks a bit greasy") (the tavern seems to be the worst looking with actual maps looking slightly better) (easy fix by turning post-processing off
date:
but I really don't understand how anyone looked at the effects and gave it an "OK!")
- Seems to be missing a few levels/costume dlcs from the original (I'm afraid they might reintroduce this as microtransactions)
- There's really no transparency from the developers of what exactly was added (or will be added in the future).  The Steam page comes off a little dishonest.

There's plenty of strange decisions for this release; but for $6
recommended: I can easily recommend it if any of the new features interest you.  Otherwise?  Maybe stay away. But
hoursPlayed: I can't say I really regret my purchase; nothing is completely experience-ruining.  If anything
voteText: it's nice to have a "new" experience with Dungeon Defenders after all these years.  The only thing that concerns me is that they might just be testing the waters for ♥♥♥♥ing over the fanbase more at a later time."

reviewText:
Don't care about the bad reviews that people with literally 0.2 hour playtime. I will provide you with a proper review for the game.
I have no idea why this game is getting so many negative reviews. In this review I want to go over some of the things that they changed about the game.
Before I start, this game is basicly Dungeon Defenders 1, with new content, and a lot of fixes.

New Content
Cash shop
The cash shop is getting a lot of hate by a lot of the reviewers. They are saying that it makes the game developers look greedy, and that they only care about money. This is false. The only thing you can buy in the cash shop, is taunts. You can buy taunts for $1 each, and there is a total of 34 taunts you can buy. It does not give you any benefits in the game, but it does make you very cool looking.

The pause menu
They have made a new pause menu for the game, which does not only look amazing, but it is amazing as well. You can now change your options in game, without having to close, and re open the game. You can once again inspect players (look at their gear and stats), you can add randoms to your party without having to add them on steam, and you can report players for different reasons, like cheating, offensive username, language and profile picture.

The tavern
They are using the same tavern as in the last game, but you are now sharing  the tavern with other players. This makes it possible for you to just sit in the tavern, and chat, make new friends, trade with randoms etc. It makes a community out of the game.

Story mode, challenges, and just maps in general.
They are using basicly all (and some new ones) maps form DD1, but they have made it so you have to complete them in order to be able to play them. This makes it so you can no longer but the game, and instantly lvl up to the max lvl. You have to work for your lvl, and you have to work for your gear. This makes it more funt o play with friends.

Pets, armor, weapons.
You can now see parts of the armor you are wearing, which is really cool. All the armor pieces does not look the same, like it does in the original game, and you no longer get armor with just +1 stats if you play on easy mode. This makes it way more balanced.
For the pets, I think they have made a huge improvement. They have made it so all lvl 1 pets comes from eggs that you need to carry around (basicly just have it in your inventory) until they hatch, and you get a new pet. All pets have special abilities that you can use (with cooldowns), plus they will fight for you, like they did in the original game.
For the weapons, I have ot noticed anything different yet, apart from the new textures.

Coins!
You no longer have to be greedy when you are upgrading your friend's towers with your mana, because you no longer use mana as money. They have made it so you get coins instead. This makes a lot more sense to me, as I think of magic, and summoning when I think of mana. I don't think about buying armor with it. You get coins about the same way you get mana. You get them form killing mobs, selling your loot, and completing maps.

Small changes
I have found a few small changes in the game too, that I think are really cool.
When you are near another player, you can see their health and mana bar over their heads. Now you don't have ti pause the game to see if anybody has any mana left!
There is a mini-map in the corner of the screen, so you don't have to enable the full-scree map to see where the remaining mana-chests are. You can just look at the mini map! You can of course use the large map too, if you perfer that.
When you are building a tower, or repairing one, there is no longer a giant progress bar showing in the middle of the screen. They made a small, but nice looking bar down in the left corner instead.
Keybinds for your forge. Now you have keybinds you can use in your forge, instead of having to click first the item, then the unlock button, you can simply click L while hovering your mouse over the item you wish to lock/unlock to do so. There are more keybinds like this.

Things I don't like about the game
It is a bit confusing the first 20 minutes
You kind of have to play DD1 to understand what's going on in this game. I guess you could always google a Dungeon Defenders Eternity tutorial".
The first time you load something

reviewText:
Time to give my 2 cents. I have put hundreds of hours into the orginial Dungeon Defenders and decided to buy this one as well. Bottom line is, I believe it IS WORTH IT. Whether you are new to the game, or already own it. It is worth the money, and they seem to be working on and fixing any problems so far. DON'T LISTEN TO THE NEGATIVE REVIEWS! Most complaints have been fixed at this point and there is still being work done. Overall, the game still plays the same as the original with some fixes and additions that arguably make the game even better! Now... let's get into it.

This review is going to written as though you played the original just to point out the reasons for buying this new version.

Pros:
-More maps
-Almost every DLC from the original comes included in this version
-Any equiptment is now visible on your character
-Pets have alternate abilities that can be activated
-Item slots for equiptment that can be activated during battle for various effects (Summon a storm cloud that deals damage, make all your attacks poisonous, heal nearby players, etc)
-Players now have there own mana chests as well as drops so no more stealing or fighting over mana/equiptment
-You can dye your character AND items
-Mana is no longer currency, instead during levels there are gold coins mixed in with the mana as enemies die
-Hardcore mode is now scary (if you die...your character is gone for good)
-Hitting control allows your character to kind of dash ahead a bit to get around a bit quicker
-running into your towers causes you to jump automatically to allow you to get over them with ease

Cons:
-Still HAVE to be online
-When completing a level, you always have to return to the tavern prior to starting a new level
-The overall userface and inventory system is a bit more clunky then usual, but is manageable
-Hardcore mode I feel is also a bit too much some times haha
-No split screen
-A store that uses REAL money (but is only for cosmetic stuff like emotes and costumes so no biggie)

Again, overall the game plays the same. Once you are actually in a match and playing through a level, you won't really notice a difference (other then a few of the new additions). Some things have even made the game better from the original! It's not as bad as those initial reviews made it seem, and although there have been some problems and it isn't perfect...it is getting there. And even as of now, it is still great and feels close to the orinigal DD we know and love. BUY IT!

reviewText: Being a veteran of the first game, I was a tad bit dissapointed. It was missing a core feature that the first game had. SINGLE PLAYER/PRIVATE MATCHING. Now that they have added this feature in, I am happy to say it is better, but still requires some work. If you liked DD1, I would get it just to try out the game, I mean why not? The grind on DD1 is hard. But for all the new ones popping in, its a great experience to hop into the realm of Etheria. Also don't be discouraged about the in-game purchases they are PURELY cosmetic. The game is essentially a one time buy with a few extra cosmetics if you want to go the extra mile.

reviewText:
I don't usually post reviews, but due to the massive negative feedback this game is getting, I feel it's necessary.

Some of the UI is a bit complicated and clunky, but it doesn't necessarily take away from the game. Just a bit of exploring, and it makes much more sense and is easier to navigate.

I understand why people are getting angry, but I think that nearly all of these reviews are overreacting. I don't think it's fair to say that you don't recommend a game after an hour or less on record. Granted, recommending it with the same amount of time isn't very convincing either.

But, this game does have a lot of added features that spice up the gameplay and make it all-around more enjoyable, in my opinion. The UI for the shop is clunky, yes, but in the actual Dungeon Defense part of the game, the UI is much smaller and easier to navigate than previously. Also, the upgrade system is much easier to understand and use. They've added Pet Eggs to make obtaining pets easier, as well as Consumables. Seriously, so much has been added from the first game, it's ludicrous.

My favorite feature is the dodging. Parkour parkour, mutha******.

Honestly, I think this game is getting way too much negative feedback considering how good it actually is. Much better than the first game, in my honest opinion. (They've added Single Player now, too, so please shhhhh.)

If you can get it for $6 thanks to the first game, do it. If you can get it at all, do it. It's worth your money in my opinion.

reviewText: This game is a fantastic remaster of the original. If you loved the first one buy this one. If not? Then stay away. But if you owned the first one, this one is only 6 dollars. How can you argue with that?

reviewText:
Eternity is most certainly different from DD1, and its not all good or bad.

From the positives such as better loot filtering and pet abilities, to the not so greats such as needing to be connected at all times and laggy response times on most actions.

In a short summary, for anyone who played the DD1 but found it lacking and abandoned the game shortly after, this game is perfect for you, but for the many who played it out through it all, this will feel like a very foreign and strange experience, it will likely be a fairly displeasing experience at first but in time you may grow to like it, i was off put at first but upon finding out about pets having active abilities i came to embrace what differences this game offered, i may not like them all but what i do like is here, so here is were i will stay.

Oh and uhm, if you havent played the first Dungeon Defenders game... ignore that one and get this one, this is basicly a remastered edition.

reviewText: For those who wrote hasty reviews before learnign the essence of what Trendy is doing here I wish you Hadn't. Let me start by saying that this game is by no mean the Origional game completely remade (It will be a different experience even playing through the old campaign!). This is also not Dungeon Defenders 2. However this is a Sincere effort by Trendy to put out a taste of what the new game will look and feel like, and give the thousands of fan of the origional a chance to start seeing some of the hard work they have been putting in. For everyone complaining about a cash shop? That is a feature that will be available likely in DD2 but in no way is Pay To Win its essentially all cosmetics that you can choose to bling out a character with new emotes or taunts.\n\nIve clocked over 1k hours in Dungeon Defenders, have 100% acheivement rate, and can say that I give this game 8.5/10 due to small annoyances like no option to replay a map, and creating a new game taking a minimum 35s in lobby countdown even if playing solo. However the controls seem nicely improved with features like character movement now auto paths over towers and terain easier. And the addition of a much more inviting Pet system are all worth while.

reviewText:
A constantly improving version of the original Dungeon Defenders,complete with its DLC.

They release almost weekly updates on big topics mentioned in the steam forums. Thumbs up for listening to the players.

The game starts off balanced,but eventually you can become more powerful than the enemies you defend against. Then they add a new monster/map. Great way to keep things fresh. I highly recommend the game in its current state,Although it's even better with 1-3 extra friends to bring along.
voteText: 7 of 16 people (44%) found this review helpful

reviewText: As someone who played the Original DD quite a bit I was wary of a new version that had to be purchased seperately and  featured much of the same content as  the first title.  Having now levelled a new character into their mid 20's I can say that this version is better than the Original.  Players no longer fight over crystal chests each round; the loot system has been tweaked for a smoother experience and the dlc from the first title has all been included and rebalanced for a better levelling experience. The UI does  have some issues with not being very intuitive on how to manage your inventory but the developers have posted that UI changes are being looked into.  As far as price goes even at its full $19.99 tag, this version is a better deal than purchasing the first title with all the dlc; so its a no brainer for anyone who hasn't already purchased the first game.  With the game servers being handled entirely by the developer, instances of cheating will hopefully be far less prevelant or nonexistent compared to the first DD.  Overall I'd say this title has some rough spots to work out as far as its UI is concerned but overall I would not tell someone to not give it a try and enjoy one of the best action/tower defense games available.

reviewText:
I own the original and all of it's DLC, I am a fan of the game so I picked this version up.

This version is horrible. The launcher is unnecessary and unattractive. The first time I tried to launch the game from it it crashed. You are now required to make an account with a servivce I have never heard of (you have to log into the account in the launcher before you can start the game). I understand that the service is providing servers to host games, which prevents hackers, but I absolutely hate how this was gone about. I'm sure another solution could have been found, or more time could have been put into implementing something such as VAC to not require another account just to launch the game. You are also immediately dropped into a multiplayer lobby with lots of people when selecting play, there isn't even a character select. This is also unnecessary and not something I think adds value to the game. I prefer starting a game and being present a menu, or at least some kind of character select, not being dropped into a game with a group of people I don't know. Oh yeah, and there are microtransactions... they went F2P without going free. My first impression upon launching this game (when I loved the original) is to stay far away. I highly recommend you don't spend money on this. Wait until the original version is on sale and pick that up- or just wait for the second one (which they hopefully haven't done the same to).

This version of the game cripples a great game with a multitude of poor and unnecessary decisions. I am upset that I spent any money on this (even if it was only $6). I normally don't write reviews, but I want to help people avoid this. It's simply sad that such a great game was put into such a miserable state like this.

reviewText:
First I gotta say - feels really good to get back into a good grinding TD experience again!
And it really is just that .. A hardcore grinding game - Perfect to take away your many leftover hours.

Sweet new spell slots they made for more personal charecter options (also able to put in eggs to increase tower stats instead)
Spells like  hero healing, tower healing, and extra field damage all found as both single target and area of effect or even personal player damage boosts for those who want to make the action themselves!
And about the eggs - Feels awesome you need to first find the egg and then hatch them into pets later and not only does it make more sence but only increase the grinding you need to do further.
They also added crafting which is a nice touch to a grinding game.

The new survival mode they made makes it interresting in a whole new way because you cant just switch your chars and make the best defence by yourself .. now you actually need team members to get the job done proberly for the whole hour!
Ofcourse for some that is also a downside, but fear not. Going beserk alone is very posible with the right spell setup!

Now that was all the good stuff ..
Dont know when any of this will be fixed but here is how it is as of now..

Just when you log in it loads just as any other time.. But nothing happens .. Cant join tavern - Awesome

Another bad thing they need to fix is the party option - and for a multiplayer game it should be crucial..?
When you are in a party and try to start a map the ready" button people need to press bugs out and you get stuck.
When a map is over and you are in a party ( if you managed to get this far ) it sometime bugs the party and the trouble starts once again..

This might not sound as much.. But when you got someone to play with and you might be able to play 1 map and then get stuck in bugs for more then 30 mins before just entering the tavern again to get stuck once more?
It makes it bad.. Really bad .. Almost like the bugs got bugs :o

But even with the current bugs solo maps seem to work fine most of the time. And what you get to play is as awesome as ever!

So besides the bugs in this game I fully recommend it! Maybe waiting abit to buy it is a smart move so they got some time to fix the bugs.. But not that it matter really when the game is this awesome!

Hopefully this gave you some answers you were looking for. Hope to see you inside Defenders!"

reviewText:
Listen up!! Here is the real review! Beware of people that are downvoting this game because of bugs. Look at the date of their review and then look to see if a patch just came out. The game acts really BAD when you click play at 25% downloaded instead of waiting for 100% and the first 3 days after a patch it acts really laggy, BUT after 3 days and 100% downloaded this game works perfectly.

Now onto the review, this is a similar game to DD1 but they remade it for transitioning into DD2. This remake allowed rebalancing to all the items and classes. There are extremely few hackers, I have only seen 2 people with hacked items in all my hours on the game. Patches are plenty and they have added new levels and minions to keep it interesting. Downsides to DD1 players are that the reduced the size and weapon effects so you can't get rediculously huge items anymore :( . It took like 4 months to finally see nightmare survival mode and mix mode still isnt out, but we will have all the blanks filled in soon I hope. Still a great game just not as addicting as DD1. If what they say is true about item transfers to DD2 then I recommend playing DDE over DD1. There are a lot of minor UI and mechanics theyve added that really make the game more enjoyable.

Still wish the game was more flashy and outrageous though.

reviewText:
If Trendy had released this game in a different way then I dont think there would be so many unhappy people.  I was a bit unsure at 1st as I felt I was paying for a game I already had but once I finnally got in the game I realised its just Dungeon Defenders 1.5.  Its the original Dungeon Defenders in the new DD2 engine so we'r basicly bug testing the DD2 engine.  It was only £4.50 so I figure I would have paid that for a map pack of 4 maps anyway.  I am a bit sad to not have all my capped chars but its nice to start fresh  :)

Likes:

The invenory is much better,  the filter and organization system they added is awesome.

New engine is nice, graphics are better and the charcters and NPC's all look better and runs well once in a game

New Maps

Instanced loot and chests


Dislikes:

Inventory Icons - the icons are far too big and difficult to look through

Tavern - I much preferred the tavern system from DD1.  Its really buggy joining the tavern and can takes loads of atempts before you get in.  I dont like the shared hub tavern, I much preferred having my own tavern and I miss all my trophies ;P

The PlayVerse joining issues need to be fixed desperatly as it takes more time to join a game than it does to play but I'm hoping this will get fixed soon (this seems to be fixed now, had no issues joining since 29/07/14)

Hardcore mode - loose all xp/gear if you fail (this is a terrible change)

reviewText:
I've seen way too many bull reviews, so here is a review with the information on BOTH sides. Hopefully this will actually help someone make the choice on if they want to get this or not. This review is admittedly mostly aimed at those that have played dungeon defenders in the past and are thinking about buying this one as well. As you have looked below, I'm sure you see the wall of text; don't worry, I will be putting bullet points at the end.

[PROS/CHANGES]
Let me start off by saying I do really enjoy both dungeon defenders, and Dungeon Defenders Eternity. As for all the wonderfull changes that are made, there isn't a single one that I don't enjoy.  We have two stats replacing the skill stats, such as the joust for countess, as Ability Offensive and Ability Defensive. They act just like they sound, with Ability Offensive helping out the offensive skill if you have one, and defensive helping the other. These two stats do play into more, but I'll get to that later. The next new thing is that you no longer only have a helmet, chest plate, pants and gloves. Now you have all those, plus greaves, belts, masks, shields and each one of those items has stats associated with it, as well as actively change the way your character looks. A nice change to actually see your equipment change your character, besides just your weapon. There is also now a crafting system, where you can randomly come across blueprints for items from monsters. From chests you gain crafting materials, and you just take those and go talk to a shroomite on the 2nd floor of the tavern, and if you have the necessary materials you can make said item. The really nice thing about this is that you actually know the stats the items is going to have before it's made, but the bad thing is that I believe once you make it once, you'll have to get another one to make it again.

Another really nice thing that falls near the same catagory, is artifacts. From beating certain bosses and challenges, you obtain artifacts that you can use (you can only use that specific artifact on that specific character once, but are not limited to only one artifact used on that character,) to give a permanent bonus toward stats, such as tower attack. Some do have level requirements as well, such as a demon one requires your character to be level 15 in order to use it on it. There are also boosts you can get that are consumables that can increase the quality, quantity and rarity of items that drop on that stage. At least, until you're done with the stage, then it reverts to normal. That being said, getting a bunch of rare items with really good stats isn't something I can complain about.

The next really big change, is in a completely new catagory called Active Items." These active items can be potions
hoursPlayed: eggs
voteText: and ability amulets. Yup
helpfulPercent: ability amulets
votesHelpful: such as "Thunderstorm Amulet
votesTotal:
that give you new spells to use. Remember those new stats I spoke of? Well, say your Thunderstorm does 70 damage every .33 seconds base. Not only does your offensive ability buff your Joust, or whatever base class ability you have, but it ALSO buffs the item abilities. So, instead of doing only 70 damage every .33 seconds, now you're doing 100 (70+30). That's just an example, mind you, so no real formula's were used. As for the eggs, it's a new way to gain pets. While your out slaughtering hapless orcs and whatnot, an egg can sometimes drop. All you do is put that egg in the active item slot, and wait until it get's enough xp to hatch. Doesn't seem to be too bad as far as the amount necessary. You already know the stats of the pet before it hatches, but not the type, so you can take an educated guess on if you want to hatch it or not. Speaking of types, pets now have a passive ability as well as active. Take a hawk, for example. It still has it's peck-like attack that does damage that it will regularly do, but it will also have a swoop active ability (On a 15 second cooldown,) that doesn't cost any mana that adds a bleed effect to anything hit by it.

Next up on the list is how things have been rebalanced, and the UI changed. If you place a turret down, say a ballista, you can still cursor over it and check it's stats - such as how much damage it does and fire rate. However, if you open your radial menu and select the tower out of that, then it will actually show you information such as the ballista's base stats, and how much YOUR stats add. It also gives you information on if certain stats, like tower speed, will affect it or not. Kinda neat, and somewhat helpeful! On the topic of rebalancing, I don't have any direct examples, but I can definitely say that after 712 hours or so of Dungeon Defenders this one definitely feels more fluid and even. Another neat thing is the dodge mechanic. You get 4 charges that replenish quite quickly, assuming you don't use them one after the other, and it gives you a horizontal leap in whatever direction your moving in. This is great for avoiding projectiles, jumping ledges, getting around the map faster or dodging that assassin that just jumped over you and is about to eviscerate your head.

All in all, lots of really, really nice changes in my opinion.

[CONS]

Nothing is perfect, and dungeon defenders eternity is no exception. The game does suffer currently from some nasty bugs, some of which I've noticed particularly with Summoner. I've had orcs moonwalk through walls off the level and dissapear. I've had ogres decide they don't like where they are and relocate to a different spot, or go suicide in pits. I've had the kobold lit fuse running at you about to explode sound looped on my headset until the round was over, even though the last kobold had died a while ago. I have teleported to my cursor's position while selecting something from the radial menu three times, though I have been unable to purposefully recreate it.

There is a ... cash shop... shudder... I place this under cons because it invites the Pay to win" aspect in games. No better example then the original Diablo 3. Thankfully

reviewText:
In some ways, this is a very pollished version of Dungeon Defenders. Lots of stuff has been fixed and streamlined. I really like the character customization options (although it is weird that we cannot choose the color of our character's hair, clothes and skin like we used to).

However, the GUI is awkward and completely different: it will take a little while to adapt. It took me a good, long while to find some basic functions. I also hate the public tavern system: some players fill the place with so many traps that it gets real laggy. Wholly unnecessary!! I'd rather just have a party-only tavern.

But once we figure out this new GUI, and the developers fix a few things, this will really rock. I'm glad that I'm giving it a chance.

reviewText:
I can't believe how incredibly negative everyone's reviews on this game are. I have never enjoyed playing the original Dungeon Defenders in multiplayer because everyone's characters were all end-game characters, or I got the impression people were playing the game just to get to higher levels- not to have fun.
Dungeon Defenders Eternity has completely switched that around for me. I'm enjoying the game with a lot of other people, some DD veterans, some new. There are some emergency maintenances which disable matchmaking, but this is overtrumped by the revamped matchmaking thanks to playverse. I've made dozens new friends in just 22 hours of gameplay.
The new abilities are also a great idea and brilliantly implemented in the game.
Definitely recommended to people who enjoy a revamped Dungeon Defenders experience without cheats!

reviewText:
I played the original DD for a long time. Some of the changes are difficult to work with. but these issues have been either resolved or are in the procces of being fixed. the only real problem is the servers at the moment. they are not very stable and often drop.

on the good side, all levels are included. classes. balance is great. i was always a fan of survival mode, and the changes they have made are great there. survival is now only 1 wave of constant enemies for an hour. survive an hour and you win ^_^. i would like to change it up and add different lengths. a 2 hour, 3 hour. these would be great... but you typically max out your loot in the hour.

i recommed this game because it includes everything i used to love. a little more confusing, and the shared tavern can burn in one of the deeper levels of hell, but all in all, i enjoy it.

*Edit- Apparently there is a level 60 limit now. it is very frustrating to be honest. My old characters were level 100. feels like a limiter on a sports car... a pointless nuisence. it is likely to help newbies level up, but its annoying.

reviewText:
Ah, Dungeon Defenders Eternity! We have a love hate relationship. I love the game, but I hate how addicted I become during my hardcore sessions!

This is a tower defense and RPG hybrid that could almost be called a reverse MOBA.

There are many lanes, crazy map layouts and plenty of heroes to choose from, but the goal is the same no matter what: Protect the crystals. If a single one is destroyed, it's game over.

The general idea is to build tower defenses like any other tower defense game and defend the crystals, but the formula has never been done like this outside of Trendy's Dungeon Defenders series.

The entire game is played from a third person perspective, and during combat, you can run around and fight enemies much like a hack and slash RPG, all while gaining experience points to level up, find awesome loot and become one of the few elite heroes that can destroy anything without any trouble.

If you like tower defense games and you want to try a new spin on the genre with many new layers, give this game a shot! You likely wont regret it!

Still under development.  Lacks many features that are already in DD1 while not offering much new yet.

Update 12-22-14

reviewText:
This game is broken and will not even launch on Linux. The developers are incompetent and clearly lack som fundamental knowledge in areas of cross-platform & operating systems outside of Microsoft Windows.

In the end they settled on (fixing) the game under Linux, by way of using a third-party, messy & half-broken work-around startup script. This script was added to the Steam launch options and suffice to say, does not work well. This alone took them months to do, while it would have taken me about 10 minutes to achieve the same.

The worst part is that litterally more than 80-90% of all other cross-platform developers on Steam could do it better and that is unacceptable. Incompetens and & lack of customer support, pure & simple.

reviewText: Why is there so much hate? I have no clue. Let me start off with Singleplayer. It's nearly the same as the first Dungeon Defenders, only with enhanced graphics, cooler weapons and awesome armor. But Multiplayer is where it gets fun. You first start off by choosing your class. No DLC characters, you have access to everybody. Once you choose your class, you get a TF2 pet equipped and press E on the eternia crystal. Then you click GO. It pairs you up with people close to your level, you will never play with anyone that is more than 5 levels above you. So you play for 10 minutes. Then 30. Then an hour. Then 4 hours. And next thing you know, it's 2 in the morning. I missed Dungeon Defenders.

reviewText: A fairly blatant cash grab, unfortunately. Game is not much different from Dungeon Defenders and the multiplayer hub has a habit of going down repeatedly, making multiplay impossible until whatever has been gone wrong is fixed, which in my experience has always taken far too long. The bottom line is that you can never scedule multiplayer with friends because you can never be sure if the service will be up or down. It also has some strange performance issure and random hitches which can really cause problems at the wrong time. As yet I haven't figured out why this is happening. I have a high-end PC which has no problems with much more demanding games, so I attribute the problem to poor optimisation or some other kind of oversight. Either way, save your money.

Ok, it's only $6, why not?

And now it's installed... and they are faced with a tavern with people from god knows where...

I LOVED the first game because they could safely play together, experiencing a mulitplayer game without the dangers and problems of a 'real' online game.

And what is it now? No split screen. No local multi-player. A separate clunky client that gets in the way when you launch it from steam.

Wow... you've really, really let yourselves down here in the rush to make as much money as possible.

Shame :(

reviewText:
Having played the original dungeon defenders and owning the entire DLC, I have to say this new version is pretty horrible.  From poorly thought out to just plain annoying, this game attempts to do everything in its power to make me not want to spend one dime on the poorly thought out microtransactions.

From being dumped in a multiplayer tavern for maximum possible lag, to having to wait in a queue to play private games, this manages to completely miss the opportunity to repair the problems it claims to be attempting to fix.

Avoid this version like the plague -- buy the original version and let this version rot.

reviewText:
This is actually good. A bit scary at first, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ UI, and I honestly think they released it too early. The fact that there was no single player or private games available honestly sucked. Thankfully, there was 4 of us ready to play in coop, so aside from the bugs here and there we actually started enjoying it.

On a side note, we'd just finished beating a boss and steam lost connection. Since this game is on a dedicated server, we didn't lose connection and still got our XP and ♥♥♥♥♥. Awesome.

Anyway, I recommend you look around and try it out, 'cause it turns out to be pretty neat.

reviewText: I've played Dungeon Defenders before, and although it's a fun game, once you get past The Summit, it's no longer fun. Sure, you can buy the DLC and it gets fun for a week, but no one wants to spend $15 for a map and challenges and then $10 for some new heroes. This version, though, is great. It's only $15 for all the DLC and characters, and it comes with a ton of new maps and weapons. The crafting system is great, since most of the armor and weapons you create are very good, and the dyeing and costumes are a great addition. In the first game, I found it wierd that the equipped armor doesn't show up on your character, but they finally included that. Over it's a great game.\n\n(9/10 Stars)

reviewText:
Haters are gunna hate!

While not perfect, this is a nice take on getting rid of the rampent hacking of the weapons and stats of the first game.  Time will tell if the online aspect will prove to stop the hacking from the first game.  That being said its good ole DD.  Few new surprises, but otherwise same game just more streamlined and simpilified.  There's a lot of gaming to be had for the entry price.  If you're like me and was a big fan of the first one, but stopped playing because of all the overpowered (and hacked) people that would ruin the games online then this will make you happy.

It has been so long since I've played DD I've been enjoying relearning the different techniques needed for the dfferent maps and making new friends along the way.



As for the people complaining about microtransactions they are only there to change the appearance of your characters, they in no way shape or form alter your characters power, stats, or abilites.  Its just for looks!

They also have been really good about addressing bugs and have been adding constant patches and updates to the game.  (in addition to adding single player options as well).



Basically if you loved the first one and want to get your Dungeon Defenders fix in again then this is a great way to do it.

reviewText: Okay so the best way to think about this game is by seeing it as a Dungeon Defenders: Game of the Year Addition. So when you purchase this game it comes with all of the dlc that was with the first, plus a few new missions. That is the most important change. There are some differences which others have repeated many times the best of which is that loot (item drops, mana, etc.) is seperate for each person. So there are no more drop hogs that pick everything up whether it belongs to their class or not, and no one picking up all the mana for themself. Also your character now wears the armour that you equip.\nSo if you already own this game on pc, yeah it might not be completly worth it to buy right now, I myself would wait for a good sale. However if you are like me and have only owned the console version of the game, with 1 piece of dlc, it is worth the buy. Especially because the console edition never recieved the additional characters the pc version had. Or if you have not purchased or played Dungeon Defenders at all I would reccomend going for this game over the original as it comes with the dlc.\nIt is good to mention that this still in fact a new" game that still has bugs

reviewText:
Love it! Better balanced, better UI, better loot system, and NO MORE HACKING -- in theory. This is what DD should've been from the get-go. Contrary to what some of the early reviews said, this is NOT just a mobile port. And there IS both single player and private party play (though you still have to be online -- that's how they prevent hackers, as everything is hosted on their servers this time).

Big changes:
===========================
* Online only play. No more hacked characters and items, hopefully. Matchmaking (presumably hosted on Trendy's servers) instead of peer to peer hosting. Hopefully no more hacked hosts.

* No split screen, level xp revamped. You don't jump from 0 to 70 with three split screen characters in Tavern Defense anymore. You actually have to earn your levels with each character.

* Towers rebalanced. Summoners now use DU like everyone else. Most towers cost less DU. EV buff beam nerfed so it's not the end-all-be-all must-have tower anymore. (Opinion: I think this is a change for the better, because now you have to think about which towers and heroes to use. It's no longer just poons + buff beams + minions. Will have to wait for higher level play to see how this turns out... but so far it seems promising.)

* Loot system redone. Everybody gets their own private loot and don't have to compete with others anymore. Much more loot variety: weapons, sets, quality levels (tiers), etc. all much better. Loot's actually useful now.

* Mana system redone: Every player gets their own mana chests (total chest mana is divided by number of players). They see their own crystals when they kill a monster. You can still drop mana for other players.

* Microtransactions were only for the new emotes. All heroes, maps, and non-legendary/super-legendary costumes are included for free. (Not sure if this is because I already own them for DD1)

* Visible armor sets and accessories for all characters. It's fun to see the Jester wear hats on her knees and belts on her hat :)

* Pets now drop as eggs that need to be incubated and then hatched. All this means is that you carry them in an inventory slot for a wave or two and then double click on them to see which pet you got. Then they level up as before. But now every pet has both their old passive ability and a new active one. For example, the genie can summon a mana aura that increases mana drops in a radius for a while. The helicopter cat can add additional damage to your next attack (almost like hawk stance). The faerie does a large AoE heal. Etc.

* A few new maps

* It uses their own Playverse service for matchmaking/chatting instead of Steam. It really sucks, is buggy as hell, and completely unnecessary. Wish they stuck with Steam.

* You can carry up to 4 activatable inventory items. There are Amulets that add skills like regeneration auras, poison DoTs, flash heals, etc. There are also bog-standard potions (healing, for example) and some one-time-use bombs, decoys, etc.

* True hardcore mode: With this on, your character permanently dies (loses all levels and equipment) if s/he falls. The best loot is found in this mode -- for those willing to risk it.

Minor changes:
===========================
* Revamped UI, with item sorting, filtering, etc. Better item comparisons. Better item and tower stats. Other quality-of-life UI enhancements: You can now filter out all lower tier weapons, for example, and then unlock them all and sell them all at once!

* Armor & weapon dyes

* Every character can hold two weapons and switch between them, like the Jester and EV could before.

* Most DLC costumes available from the get-go, without needing requirements or additional payments. Legendary and Super Legendary costumes still need to be earned, if they're in the game at all (not sure yet).

* Consumable items (health potions and whatnot)

* In-game currency is now gold coins instead of mana. Most chests, monsters, etc. drop coins. You can also sell items for coin. Coinage is abundant at least in the early game.

* Currently, the real-world money shop only sells emotes for your costumes. Not sure if they'll add more things later.

* You can make a short forward dash several times before needing to recharge it (basically a sprint)

* Finally, rebindable keys (or Xbox 360 buttons -- including readying and dropping mana!)

* Borderless full screen mode

* Minor graphical updates

* You can now type full sentences in chat! No longer limited to the previous 70 or so characters.

Conclusion
==========================
Definitely worth it for $6. I've switched to this for the online play alone, to be free from hackers, and probably won't go back to DD.

reviewText:
Overall a solid upgrade from the original Dungeon Defenders, and I spent hundreds of hours on that game.

It appears they've made a solid effort to remove the hackers from the game. While the hackers in the original game didn't ruin the game (we're all against the monsters anyway), it did cheapen the experience. Perhaps now Level 100" will actually be a sign you're competent enough to take lead on a defense.

I am slightly disappointed by the Summoner nerf (using DU instead of MU) but it's probably for the best. All master builds in the original needed to take full advantage of a maxed Summoner since the MU was independent of DU."

reviewText: Eternity is a revamped overhaul of the orginal Dungeon Defenders. reviewText:
((Review reworked 24/7/14 - yes, this could be considered 'in constant development'.))

Playing Games with Bad Reviews so you, my friends, won't have to if it's a bad buy! ...is my personal motto for this review, because I've heard a lot of bad things about this. Like, a lot of bad things. Like, seriously, this game had severely negative reviews when it first launched and I can't blame them. It is supposed to be the definitive Dungeon Defenders experience, and while it may be shaping up to be one, I can't help but feel... well... annoyed, and somewhat disappointed.

Upsides/What is new

Now, first things first, this game is basicaly DD1 with a new engine, there's no two ways about that, the game has been rebalanced and tweaked and looks better in some ways, looks worse in others. It still plays pretty much the same: Build towers, kill monsters, collect loot. The upside to this is that DDE has all the heroes and their costumes unlocked for you right out the gate, well, whatever was in DD1, anyway, who knows if they'll offer costumes as a microtransaction.

The game plays just as well as the original, with a few QoL tweaks like client-side mana and equipment (thank goodness), the fact that the currency is replaced with gold coins so that you no longer feel the need to leave mana out on the field, the ability to AUTOMATICALLY JUMP OVER SMALL OBSTACLES (10/10! GotY!) and the fact that there's more equipment slots plus the ability to weapon swap in the middle of a wave even if you're not Series EV (which is her gimmick back in DD1, although it seems useless now because her towers are pretty good for support.).

The UI is decent enough to fuss about with, it's not terrible, but it sometimes feels a bit clunky like the item box interface. No idea how crafting works, and my hotkeys get reset everytime I go back to tavern. There's not much of a tutorial to figure anything out if you're a newcomer, although some veterans reportedly had some trouble with it as well.

Taverns are now public... that's something I'm not too sure about, sure, it's nice to see other people in the tavern but some people don't like to see strangers running around, spamming attacks, towers, and so on. I tend to ignore such things, preferring much to get out of there as soon as I can.

Downsides/Problems

When this game first released, and this is going to be an understatement, there was a terrible fuss over how the game was missing some of its advertised features. Single-player and private lobbies? Patched in after the fact. Cards and Workshop? I dunno when that came in, but they're there now. Third-party accounts? Not advertised at launch, but there now. Always-online DRM? Not what most people were expecting. Cash shop? Bluh.

However! The company seems to be putting a small effort into fixing a few things if what they've been doing didn't tip anyone off, so at least they're trying to make things work.

So, acknowledgements of missing things at Day 1 and general fussery aside, what's the problem here?

The servers breaking in the first few days of launch doesn't really come as a surprise to me, these days. It's probably just me, but I just don't really expect any company to handle their launches very well, but perhaps I've been jaded by seeing so many online games releasing and then buckling under the pressure of people coming onto the server and breaking them. When I first played this, they were fine, although it was after the initial surge, I believe, or I was playing at a quieter time.

The cash shop in a paid game kind of rubs me the wrong way, although they're selling cosmetics right now, so that kind of mitigates it, it's still a cause for concern. Right now, I don't feel too strongly about it, but I would feel wary about it, just in case.

Overall

All in all, this is not a bad game, but it's been sullied by how it was handled right out of the gate, and that doesn't put a lot of trust in their customers. The price for this is questionable, but having a hefty discount for owning the game plus the initial release sale at this time of writing brings it down to a price I can somewhat agree with. Sure, I'd prefer it to be more or less free or be a patch for DD1, but if they insist on it having a price, then so be it, but the initial asking price right now for a small upgrade doesn't fit the bill, perhaps when it is more fleshed out then the price would have more worth to it.

Anyway, it is up to you as to whether or not you should buy it. If you don't particularly care much for Trendy's antics and want to play Dungeon Defenders, this could be a good pickup for what it's worth since it has the Eternia Shards levels packed in with it. However, if registering a separate account on Playverse and having a game that requires you to always be online irks you, but you still want this game, I suggest you go pick up DD1 over this.

Side note: I honestly wish there was an undecided option for reviews on Steam whenever the reviwer is unsure on whether to recommend it or not, like in my case. Honestly, what happens in the future can tip my view on this game in whatever side's favour.

reviewText:
Like many of the people complaining, I also sank a LOT of money on the original DD. With that being said though, that game and community were completely dead for me. The fact that people could get anything they wanted just by running a program in the background killed it for me in every sense of the word. This game has been given new life with this release making it a LOT harder for people to just hack and get what they want. One cool/weird thing they did with this game though is you don't download anything until you need it. That means when you first start the game, EVERYTHING is going to be super blurry. Just give this some time and it will pass as you download the required files. So far this game has been wonderful and fun to play again and really helped revive a game that just wasn't fun to play anymore.

--UPDATE--

After playing this game for almost 60 hours now after its first release I can honestly say that the game is better than its previous counterpart. While the game is still going through some growing pain as far as the servers adjusting to the player load, the staff seems to be really helpful and quick to fix any issues that come up. The staff also takes a lot of what people are saying in the forums and fix what needs to be fixed.

-- Conclusion --

If your reading all these posts saying stuff like THE SERVER IS DOWN
hoursPlayed: there is no single player" then your just reading peoples first impression. Even WOW couldn't keep their servers playable for the first couple days and DD is doing a way better job than they did. The single player is now enabled due to popular demand. reviewText:
Most people try to focus on one aspect of this game. I'm going to approach this game from many angles and enlighten the potential buyers what to expect.

(-)First: The player verse menu. I'm not a fan of it. It’s a little glitchy and the interface is not very clean. But it is semi functioning… as long as the servers are working correctly.

(+/-)Second: Always online. Most people complain about this. I like it. For people that like to split screen and play solo w/o interwebs. Stick with original DD.

(+)Third: The overall changes and rebalances are nice. I like the options and the customizations of DDE better.

(+)Fourth: They have frequent updates and feedback.
Worth $15? No
Worth the $5? Yes

reviewText:
I started Playing this game not long after release, it was glitchy and bug riddled.  It got to the point where frequent roll backs meant that it was impossible to progress.

So I left the game to be patched for a month or two, I saw many patches released and lots of bug fixes.
Feature were re-added to the game, yes re-added as they were present in the original and not this version.
The developers were trying their best, and they were communicating with the players.  I wanted to give them the chance to produce a good game.

I fired the game up again today to get back in to it, I left it to patch for a while and then clicked play.

Now the game is so bad it doesn't even start any more and just sits on the menu screen without the option to begin playing, just the option to go in to the options menu.

I really wanted to like this game, I loved the original, but this has just been a let down from the start.

reviewText:
Being a big fan of the 1st game along with a really good sale of this one i decided to get it, and dont regret it.
i'm not going to go through a whole list of positive things about the game as their are so many, though i'm going to have a little moan about things they got right in the first game and so wrong in this 1.

Private Taverns: i dont want to be lumbered with no escape from a bunch of other players spam attacking dummys and skills in the tavern, me and my mate play mainly at night till early hours in the morning due to being busy during the day, and to have a private tavern to talk about the items picked up and the next fight and tactics and stuff was perfect, now we're dumped in a zoo of 20-30 other people going mental.

User Inteface: The UI in this game feels rushed, trading is useless unless you wish to spend an hour looking for the item you said your mate could have when you picked it up, as the icons are so small in the trade box and you cant tell the difference between a staff and a sword.
An added filter for class would be great, their are a few filter choices to help you look for specific items in your inventory, but their is no filter that allows you to look for specific class items, if you have a few characters that you would like to progessively level and gear up, this would be a huge bonus.
Their are a few other issues with the UI but you get the idea.

Loading times: The loading times are starting to annoy me a little. Because i'm so used to the game loading instantly in DD once a level is picked and now this whole countdown waiting for player stuff has been implemented it needs to be tweaked slightly. Add a check box that allows players that are ready to tick, and if all players have loaded and ticked, they can begin instead of waiting for the whole countdown, me and my mate have monstrous gaming pc's, 95% of the loading time is us waiting about.

Trading: i know the game has its reasons for having our own client side loot, and it is great i enjoy not fighting over loot anymore, but it would be nice if i could just right click an item in my inventory and click drop and it becomes server side, when playing with more than 2 friends its time consuming clicking trade on each person when if a drop" feature was implemented everyone in the game could mouse over the items i dropped to see if they are better and take them
date: if not ill scoop them all back up
recommended: i miss that.\n\nThese are just a few of the problems in this game in comparison to the first
