reviewText:
I will be making comparisons to the original Dungeon Defenders, so I apologize to those who have not played it as this review will be difficult to understand. Do note that this review is solely based on how the game is in its current state (as of July 25, 2014). There will be changes made as the developers iron out the bugs.

This is essentially Dungeon Defenders 1.5, so if you enjoyed the original, you will enjoy this even more (assuming you can get over the fact that you have to start over). However there will be certain exceptions. Although there have been some MAJOR improvements when it comes to the loot, leveling, stats and gameplay in general, it comes at a cost. This game REQUIRES you to be online, at all times. Not only this, but you must also have a decent connection in order to be able to play without monsters lag-warping all over the place. While this issue does not really affect the tower-defending portion of the game, it will hinder some players from being able to properly fight mobs up close. This game also contains its fair share of bugs, and requires you to sign up for a Playverse account (relatively painless however).

While many people will say that it contains every DLC from the past game, there are a few noteable exceptions. In the game, the maps are divided between Campaign, Lost Shards Campaign, the new Campaign (only one map in it so far), bonus maps (Glitterhelm, Palantir and such), challenge maps (Raining Goblins, etc.) and another grayed-out tab that has crossed swords as an image. I found that most of the combat-oriented maps are missing, the Presidential PvP map, the two-team tower defense, the Assault maps and other similar maps. However I speculate that the grayed-out tab has something to do with that.

While most of this that I mentioned in my review here is already mentioned on the store page, I feel that it helps to repeat these as they are important factors when it comes to deciding whether or not you wish to purchase the game.

I enjoyed this new remake of the old Dungeon Defenders, however I was one of the lucky who were able to get the game to work from the start, and have no issues with connectivity so far. I've also been lucky enough not to suffer from the hardcore glitch (they have disabled hardcore mode until they fix it) which causes you to suffer the consequences of hardcore even if you haven't died. I know not everyone will be so lucky, so you could take this as a warning.

reviewText:
Only played the first level and messed around with items, store, forge etc. But so far I can't really see what people are complaining about too much. Will update this once I played more this weekend.

>edit

Okay so after playing for a bit longer tonight, the only real complaint I have is that of the new tavern system. Anyone familiar with DD will have spent a lot of time in their OWN tavern, but now you have to be in a public tavern, and connection issues galore a lot of the time you can't even connect to one. This leads me with the issue of sitting at the end of a game for 10 minutes trying to leave so I can start a new one, but unable to go to my own tavern, it's really frustrating, I spend more time waiting than I do playing...

Another annoyance is that you can't make your own public game. So if you want to play public, you have to play with people you don't know. Yes, you can create a private game, but what if I want to level up a DPS character and can't solo some of the larger maps (for example), and can't be bothered to use my builder? This means that you can either play with randoms, some of which are bad... not blaming them, some people might not have played DD to my extent, but I don't want to play with new people at the moment, I want to experience the new and improved" end game. And sometimes it can even take 5-10 (sometimes longer) to even FIND a game for your level/difficulty/map... So the only other option is a private game.

Other than that I'm enjoying my time
date: I think I'll wait until the connection issues are fixed and I can actually host a public game and/or tavern to remove the complaints I talked about above.\n\nIf you're a veteran DD player and you have the $$$ to spare

reviewText:
This is Dungeon Defenders 1: Complete Edition.  Without hacking, with some extra content.  As such it gets my full endorsement.  As someone who came to the party late, there was no point in playing public multiplayer due to the hacking.  This game finally allows me to play the original as it was meant to be played.

Despite early reviews, this is not:

1) A mobile port (this is a complete misunderstanding of the cross platform service launching later)
2) Full of microtransactions. The only thing you can (currently) buy are useless Emotes for $1 - all skins and dyes are earned as usual, as are all weapons, armor, etc.
3) Dumbed down or DLC deficient - the gameplay is identical, and the UI is largey the same or slightly streamlined
4) Lacking single player or private matches (both were added with a day 2 patch)

They did add a uPlay-like launcher to the game that might annoy some, but I found it to be seamless.  They need the overlay to offer cross playform play later on, which steam cannot do.

Drawbacks:
- You cannot import your characters.  This is to prevent item hacks from exploiting this game also.
- They added too much bloom.  Hopefully a patch will allow you to turn it off.

Cons:

reviewText:
Before I mention what's good or bad about the game I think the reason this game was made should be stated.
The main reason this game was made is to hype up Dungeon Defenders 2 and to also test their playverse system.
So with that fact lets move to the pros, cons and they idk.

pros:
complete player reset, some wont find to this be a pro but this allows for new players to have a better multiplayer experience.
gear rework, they've managed to even out the gear progession so that becoming level 74 or higher doesn't make you a god in dungeon defenders with mythical etc.
New maps, who can complain about a few more maps and bosses.
visible armour, It's a small pro but its makes every character look unique which is always good
open tavern, Now this is a con if you prefer to be on your own but if you're like me a prefer to socialise it's a big plus.
loot rework, They've made it so the loot that someone sees is invisible to everyone else meaning that some of the more greedy players can no longer go around spamming e.
The ability to charge, I'm an extremely slow tower squire right now so the fact that I can charge helps alot for moving around the map it also allows you to leap backwards to dodge an enemy attack helping in close range combat.
You can also play at 4% allowing thos who can't wait for it to fully download to jump right in and play though you will experience slow loading times as 96% percent of the content hasn't even been downloaded.(Those of you who say It's 25% are wrong as the download to 25% is 51mb but the whole download is 1.61gb meaning It's 4%.)

Cons:
The enemy pathing is terrible I've noticed that enemies will not walk in the right path and will instead walk in circles at times.
The loot you find isn't always for your class, many times I've found a awesome sword to only realise it's a small monk weapon.
This may be a personal con but I hate the fact that the tavern keeper no longer sells weapons or armour.
buffs, agian this might be a personal thing but the fact that you can buy bombs etc makes it feel like the tower strategy has been made slightly easier.
For thos who have never bought Dungeon defenders have to pay 20 while I should be 15 euro out of sale(I'm from Ireland so I only have the Irish price.)
If you want to play a private game they make you wait through a 33 second timer.
They made the gui aimed towards phones making it akward to use. once you learn the shortcut keys it is slightly easier to use

The idk:
The fact that people can't host games is both a good and bad thing as It helps players find other players who want to play the same map but it also makes it very hard to setup a party of players who can work together properly e.g my first public game was throne room but  when I join my party was me and 3 barbarians luckily I could carry the team with my towers but if I had never joined that team was doomed from the start.
There is microtransactions but they are emotes and in all my time playing Dungeon Defenders I don't think I ever used an emote so I can't say they're a good or bad thing.

Conclusion:
This game is in a grey zone as you can't call it a cash grab from dungeon defender fans as It's 6 euro right now
but you also can't call it a new game as even though it has new things It's still the same game at its core.
If your a fan of dungeon defenders you'll probably buy it anyway but if your a new comer think it through before you buy it as I think the 20 euro price tag is too high for a game that was released 3 years ago.

reviewText:
Wow, this game is terribly dissapointing!
The promos all look very good, right? New features, new interface, all the DLC character packs, new levels, etc.
But oh boy is that ever not what you get.
There are some improvements, definately, and it is nice to have a version of the game that runs stably on Mac (original DD has lots of unresolved crash bugs on Mac). I like the new money system (gold coins instead of mana points), and new types of equipment (like talismans which give you special abilities), and I like how they've done the pets (they start in eggs now! You don't know what it will be until it hatches!), but the overall experience of the gameplay is miserable. It is very laggy and the controls are poorly responsive. Enemies attack while stunned, which makes short ranged attacks pretty much worthless. You can't play through the campaign be progresing through levels in a story-like format, you have to return to the tavern after each level. Final waves don't sell junk automatically, so if you want the points for it you have to collect it all and sell it back manually, which is a real nuisance.

Dungeon Defenders (the original) is an exceptional game, and as this one is basicaly a redesign of that, it is a fairly good game as well. But I will be sticking with the original. I just wish I could have the improvements of DDEternity with the smooth controls and gameplay of classic DD.

reviewText:
Eternity is a remake/remaster of the original Dungeon Defenders. While it's got some changes (some of which I'd prefer to have remained unchanged), the core gameplay is the same. The game is rebalanced, equipment generation has been rewritten, and a lot of complaints have been addressed. Only a few maps were taken out, and new maps have replaced those ones, and there's a new campaign to be discovered. I don't like how the tavern is shared now, and I wish you could still customize character color, but other than that, complaints are few and far between. It's effectively the Game of the Year edition for Dungeon Defenders, and those who loved the first game may not even mind starting all over from scratch. Especially since the new servers and the Playverse are all Trendy. So right now, in the beginning, is most likely the worst they'll ever be.

Edit:
As the game is being updated, I feel I should update the review. The game continues to be a fun and exciting experience, obviously better with friends. Apart from the occasional hiccup in server activity and a few glitches here and there, everything is running smoothly, and I'm very happy with the game. It's getting better, and I still recommend it.

reviewText:
Dungeon Defenders Eternity is a bit of a surprise to most. A game that changes up the multiplayer aspect of the original Dungeon Defenders game to better protect itself from cheating (which was apparently a huge concern for the original game) is now caught in ethical crossfire as to whether or not it should be a free update or what-have-you regarding those who owned it.

In the end it doesn't matter. A game stands at $19.99 for a redeveloped online-only release of Dungeon Defenders using the same back-end that Dungeon Defenders 2 will use. Is it fun? Very much so. Just like the original game I've found myself addicted to the game and found it even cutting into sleep these past few days.

Build Towers, defend crystal, level up, get stats, fight again with a harder map or difficulty. DDE supposedly improves this aspect by making a rebalance pass on items, making it a little more fair when it comes to upgrades. While I didn't have trouble in the first game, it is nice to know things were looked at a second time.

As far as items go, you now have them actually displayed on your character. Get a helmet for your summoner? Shows in game. All these items can also be dyed, which in turn gives a much more personal touch on the game as you play through.  Pets also have a new mechanic that allows you to find eggs and hatch them. While so far it feels like an extra step to the process of obtaining gear, I have a strong suspicion that there is more to it than first appears.

Some new content has also been added. Challenges and maps that are supposed to be a bridge from Dungeon Defenders and it's sequel while allowing you to earn gear for when Dungeon Defenders 2 comes out. This is interesting as I personally can't wait to see what challenges there will be.

Since the game is online-only, there are some issues with performance. Server latency can impact the game as can disconnects in the newly tuned Hardcore mode.  This also means those with poorer quality connections may have trouble with this version of the game, however this was done with the intent of keeping all user data server-side to prevent tampering. For those that were frustrated about the cheating going on in the first game, this may be the solution (though admittedly it may cause a bit of grinding teeth since it isn't a patch.)

If you haven't played Dungeon Defenders before, now is a great time to get into it. $19.99 and you get almost all the content that was released in the first game, plus a little more in a secure environment. For those who owned the first game and its DLC, it becomes a much more difficult decision. Did you want a safe environment to play, or did you stick to solo or private matches in the first place? Where you frustrated with balance issues in later game modes?

At $10.99 it's hard to recommend to existing players if they truly didn't have issues with the first game. However, at a lower price (like at the time of this review) it's much easier to make a compromise and move up for $5.99 instead.

I like the game and while some of this business leaves a bad taste in my mouth, it's hard to not enjoy what time I have with it.

reviewText: Dungeon Defenders Eternity is a revamped version of the original Dungeon Defenders. Owners of the original Dungeon Defenders can purchase this game for a discount, giving all the more reason to purchase this game. Upon hearing of it's release, I bought it immediately, despite the criticism it had gained over the first few hours of it's launch. I can certainly say that some of the complaints were justified, but most of the main problems have been patched out of the game, along with balance tweaks and more. Micro-transactions are contained within the game, but are only tied to cosemtic taunts in game, that do nothing to benefit the player, other than look cool. Dungeon Defenders Eternity also comes with most of the DLC from the original game, including all the characters, the Lost Eternia Shards DLC, and the start of a new campaign. It also contains the ability to transfer items to the upcoming game Duneon Defenders II. This game gets a solid 8/10, and is recommended to purchase over the original Dungeon Defenders, both to DD veterans, and beginners alike.

reviewText:
At first look it seemed like a un-needed mobile-esque update to the original HOWEVER, and there is a however, after approximately 2 hours of playing my Series-EV char 'Clanketta' I realised that I was far more interested than I had originally thought, despite the odd UI in the item box and hero inventory the game is still capturing some of the original DD flare with new additions that are a huge plus to the experience.

The first thing that really caught my attention was the eggs, I love being able to fight through the horde to find, and loot a pet egg, look at its stats and try to guess what it will be. Having to incubate an egg by fighting with it equipt and waiting (im)patiently for it to be ready to hatch was a lot of fun, I have a seperate folder in my Item box for eggs and pets, I currently have a Shoddy Shroomite with 22 upgrade levels, which is great as you dont invest coin to upgrade them, but fight alongside them to get XP for them.

Secondly was the addition of visable armour, nothing surprised me more than noticing I had not only the witch kings great helm on, but a tiny little crown sitting atop it, not the most ferocious looking but still novel and fun, adding dyes to armours and skins was a interesting edition as I can finally get back into the customization of my character and I actually have to work towards it.

The game has enough new features to outweigh the current teething problems on the serverside with the occasional drops and inability to join games (sorted by hosting private and publicizing it). With responsive and active dev teams working on the community highlighted issues (such as the odd UI) I feel that given time DDE will be the true 'definitive' version we were promised.

Many negative reviews are given from the perspective of those who like DD and refuse to accept any variance from their accepted view of what is right" for the series
date: however after logging several hours in both games I have found that most of the faults they find are all without any real impact other than the server problems which is common across nearly all new releases.\n\nIn conclusion
hoursPlayed: this should prove to be more of a gem than people are giving it credit for."

I still think the graphics are a little over saturated. but the gameplay is more balanced. The hot-bar is drag and drop. the new amulets are fun. showing your armor will be cool when you stop replacing it every other wave. The item UI still needs a little more polish but over is OK once you get used to it. Instanced loot is something I never knew I really needed until now. And for all those wondering what the real changes are: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=290092757

that is a post with all the new stuff in comparison to the old. It's a new game, with a lot of the old still there and is worth giving two shots. I'm glad I did.

OLD POST:
As it is, I feel like i'm playing an old beta version of the original DD. It seems like they pushed everything so hard for the mobile version that they forgot that PC exists. I played through a few levels on a mage. First thing I noticed, the num-keys don't put down the turrets anymore, only 8 through 0 does, everything else you have to click through the menus to place. Hardcore now loses items and all levels??? I can see all the levels at level 0 but have to play though to unlock them. The UI somehow seems less polished than the original. The colors seem way off and less sharp (and a lot darker). I'll come back in a week and see how things are. until then back to DD for me.

reviewText:
I was skeptical of this at first, with 600 hours in DD1, hating the RNG/end-game MASSIVE grind. but so far I'm super pleased with this.

Pros:
- All DLC is included (Although holiday dlc maps seem to not be in it), which means all that we no longer get the classic Oh damn
date: I haven't bought that map/character"\n- New equipment slots like a shield slot for everyone
recommended:
two weapon slots allowing a backup elemented weapon (Like Series EV/Jester in Vanilla)
4 new maps (And probably more coming)
- So far the item RNG seems to be better (Can't tell because I haven't reached end-game yet)
- Equipment actually shows on your character (I think you can turn this option off)
- Mana is no longer the out of combat currency
hoursPlayed: enemies (and chests
voteText: and sold loot) now gives Gold Coins!\n- New slots for Consumables and Amulets that give you up to 4 new skills to use in battle
helpfulPercent: ranging from a simple health potion(Consumed on use!) to an amulet that lets you summon a thunder storm (With a cooldown of 60s)\n- Each pet now comes with it's own activated ability. i.e. Engineer lets you do a blast repair in an area
votesHelpful: or the Heavy lets you buff you and surrounding allies' Hero damage for a period of time!\n- Summoner's Minions now use Defense Unit(DU) instead of having their own Unit pool. I think this is a plus because I felt we were being forced to use Minions as they effectively doubled (Or even triple since you don't need to use up half their points as walls) your defense strength / amount of placeable towers for damage.\n- All loot is instanced! No more loot ninjas! All Chests are instanced to you (and whatever come sout of them)
votesTotal: I think dropped mana from enemies is NOT instanced though! So be fair for that
votesFunny: but all other loot
commentsCount: go nuts!\n- New Dash feature that lets you do some quick jumps ala UT/Quake style! (Although you have a stamina bar and right now you can only do it via the ctrl key
column16:
so no double tapping a direction for now)

Cons:
- It costs extra (But overall it's cheaper for new players
column17: and 70% off for owners of DD1 now
column18: which I feel is fair as the dev's have obviously put in a bunch of effort.\n- Always online (I think this is ALSO a plus
column19: stops hackers
column20: allows you to play while the big/highrez textures stream in (First time only
column21: so expect some blurry textures at first but trust me they do get better)\n- In-App Purchases (But these are purely costmetic
column22: right now they're just $1 emotes)\n- Public Tavern (Which is actually really good for some people but for me it causes big lag)\n- Slow internet means you will get lag
column23: no matter your settings in game
column24: but I think it's bareable. (Like mine
column25: damn having bad internet in Australia)\n- Having to start from scratch even though you might have already spent hundreds of hours in DD1\n- Splitscreen/Local Co-Op has been removed. (I'm hoping for it to return though
column26: as this is a huge con for me)\n- Survival Mode is forced "Continuous" which means (at the moment) No switching characters
column27: and no chance to either stop
column29: for the slow ones out there like me
column30: loot/upgrade/repair without worrying of a DEW stabbing you in the ♥♥♥♥.\n- Textures start off super low res (But this is so you can get in the game faster) and download overtime as you play (As do maps)
column31: this can cause extra lag and make the game look very bad graphically
column32: but just give it time and those sweet sweet graphics we've come to know and love will come rushing in! (It's a first time thing for everything
column33: but after that first time everything will already be downloaded and therefore not a blurry low-res mess.\n\nAll in all
column34: I'm glad I bought it and will continue to play (hoping end-game RNG is fixed so we don't get max level gear with -50 stats)\n\nEDIT: I will be updating this as I experience new/more parts of the game!"

reviewText: The extra modes and maps more than justify the price, even if you already own the previous dungeon defenders title, as someone who personally commented and aided in one of the first official reviews of the first game, i can say without a doubt that this game is one of the best indie games on sale today in the tower defence genre.\n\nEven when youve beaten the game in all its modes and difficulties, there is nothing to stop you from doing so with the other classes you can choose, if you are a completionist, or strives for the most awesome loot for a particular character, and being able to do it with friends, comparitively with games such as torchlight, diablo, titan quest, but put it into the form of a third person tower defence game, then this game will scratch that itch for you, with its charm, light humour, and mindless destruction of all the foes you may face!

reviewText:
I own original dungeon defenders

DD1:
Had an enormous amount of content.
However content became balanced around the huge amount of cheaters that then destoryed the balanced economy of items.
Thus making the game balanced around obsurdity. Maps and gameplay very unrefined.
Offline mode to prevent playing with cheaters. But game balanced around the OP stats everyone had online. That is what I meant by obsurdity.

DD1E:
Has limited options and maps when compared to original (very disappointing)
Nearly no hackers since game files are on company owned equipment.
I feel the items were earned through player efforts making the average item level economy feel more justified.
Honestly this is the more refined version of dungeon defenders.
****This is where we should of started so people wouldn't have ranted.****

I honestly miss a lot of the content but if they release it later. No problem.
However the lack of cheaters in this game is to much of a pro to pass up

*Since steam's game value system only is a thumbs up or a thumbs down. Rather then a numeric value system. I will have to lean towards thumbs up. That's because of conversion rounding. LOL, why isn't there a meh horizontal hand.
